item.title: War | Thailand accused Cambodia of violating airspace with 250 drones
item.description: Thailand yesterday accused Cambodia of violating the current ceasefire agreement by sending 250 unmanned aerial devices (drones) over Thai territory. The Thai Army indicated that more than 250 drones were detected entering the country in the border area. For the Thai Armed Forces, Cambodia's action constituted a provocation and a violation of measures “aimed at reducing tensions” between Bangkok and Phnom Penh. At the time of writing, the Cambodian authorities had not commented on Thailand's accusation regarding the airspace violation. The two countries reached a ceasefire on Saturday after three weeks of clashes along their 800-kilometre common border, following two days of negotiations in China. The ceasefire agreement provides for an end to weeks of fighting along the disputed border, which has left more than 100 people dead and more than half a million displaced in both countries. Thai Foreign Minister Sihasak Phuangketkeow and his Cambodian counterpart Prak Sokhonn met in southwest China's Yunnan province for talks mediated by his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi. The head of Chinese diplomacy stated that Beijing “does not want to see Thailand and Cambodia on battlefields”. During a meeting with his Thai counterpart, Sihasak Phuangketkeow, on Sunday, Wang Yi expressed China's “deep concern” about the “tense situation on the border” and argued that, once the fighting stops, “diplomacy must take the lead”. “Rebuilding peace is the desire of the people and the expectation of all parties,” said the head of Chinese diplomacy, adding that Beijing’s mediation efforts “never impose themselves on others, nor go beyond limits” and aim to create “a relaxed platform for dialogue.” A fatal history US President Donald Trump, who threatened to suspend trade privileges if Thailand and Cambodia did not agree to a ceasefire in July, suggested yesterday that fighting between Thailand and Cambodia “will momentarily cease” and stated that the United States “has become the true United Nations”. The territorial limits have been disputed for decades and were inherited from the French colonial period. According to official figures, recognized by the United Nations, the latest clashes caused 47 deaths: 26 on the Thai side and 21 on the Cambodian side. In July, the first phase of clashes left 43 dead in five days, before a ceasefire was agreed. Another agreement was subsequently signed on October 26 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in the presence of the President of the United States, but was suspended by Thailand after several Bangkok soldiers were injured in the explosion of a military land mine in the border area.

item.title: Weddings | Si Ka Lon wants Macau to be like Las Vegas
item.description: Representative Si Ka Lon argues that Macau should invest in the wedding industry for tourism purposes, similar to what happens in Las Vegas. In an oral question presented to the Government, which will be answered in the Chamber next week, the deputy argues that “‘destination weddings’ is one of the directions for the development of the tourism industry”. Si Ka Lon asks whether local authorities will “take as a reference the successful experiences of Las Vegas or Hong Kong, allowing marriage registration in Macau, regardless of the place of residence or nationality of the bride and groom, with a view to exploring the 'wedding tourism' market”. In the deputy's view, the Executive can “take advantage of Macau's advantages and singularities”, investing in the promotion of “plans for outdoor wedding ceremonies, in order to increase the competitiveness of Macau's wedding tourism products and create a new business card for the city”.

item.title: Money exchange | Raid targets 60 million Hong Kong dollar deal
item.description: The Judiciary Police (PJ) announced the arrest of two women for allegedly being involved in illegal exchanges of money for gambling at a casino in Cotai. According to police estimates, the business operating in a jewelry store had a turnover of more than 60 million Hong Kong dollars, with profits being 1 million Hong Kong dollars. The detainees are a 36-year-old local resident and a 27-year-old woman from Mainland China. Both performed sales roles in the commercial space. At yesterday's press conference in which the case was presented, PJ representatives admitted that they were currently investigating the whereabouts of the owner of the commercial space. In addition to the arrests, around 500 thousand Hong Kong dollars in cash were seized. A cell phone was also seized, which was allegedly used to arrange money exchanges. The investigation was based on anonymous complaints that alerted authorities to the possibility that illegal money exchanges were taking place inside the store. The arrests took place after the agents spent a day monitoring what was happening in the commercial space, having decided to act after seeing three customers with “suspicious behavior”. The store had been operating in the casino, which was not identified, since 2019, and the two employees confessed to exchanging money. The prisoners received salaries of 13 thousand patacas and 15 thousand patacas, which included overtime pay.

item.title: New Year's Eve | Street parties and concerts to end 2025
item.description: Macau and Hong Kong will be in full swing tonight with celebrations that will welcome 2026. With paid and free options, Macau and Hong Kong offer a range of options for various tastes. One of the initiatives comes from the Cultural Institute (IC) and is already a tradition. The end of 2025 is celebrated next to Praça do Lago Sai Van from 10pm, and from 9pm at the Taipa Houses-Museum, with the “New Year’s Eve Concert – Macau 2025” and the “New Year’s Eve Party – Taipa 2025”. Various singers and musical groups perform at the concert on the peninsula side, between 10pm and 12:10am, including Hong Kong singer Panther Chan and rock band Dear Jane. There is also a cast of local artists such as Soler, Filipe Tou, KC Ao Ieong, winifai, Jenny, thetiredeyes and Initial B, “who will alternate [performances] to present a diverse range of music to celebrate a dazzling New Year's Eve”, describes the IC. Regarding the concerts at the Taipa Houses-Museum, the theme will be “Multicultural Integration”, with the public being able to see performances by FIDA, Tuna Macaense, Bossa Eva and João Gomes & Band and Karen Tong, a singer from Hong Kong. In addition, there will be performances by the Bollywood Dreams Group, by Victor Kumar, and the Filipino dance groups of the Macau Bisdak Association and Burmese and Vietnamese dance groups from Macau. The poster is completed with magic presentations by magician Jason Fong. The Portuguese is described “as one of the biggest international Fado stars, being recognized for her own musical style, which incorporates elements of soul, jazz and gospel”. Looking at Cotai, gaming operators bet heavily on year-end programs. The Venetian Arena concert hall hosts the third and final in a series of concerts by Jason Zhang, which began on Monday. Tickets range from MOP680 to MOP2,580 for VIP seats. Jason Zhang Jie was born in 1982 in China and debuted in the “My Show” competition in 2004, becoming the winner, which gave him access to a contract with Universal Music China. At the end of 2023, he already had 15 albums recorded and a total of 87 concerts in his career. Still at the Venetian, as well as at The Parisian Macao and The Londoner, there will be fireworks, with the traditional countdown until 2026. The “Sands New Year’s Eve Countdown Extravaganza” event starts with music at 9:30 pm. Like Sands China, the gaming operator Galaxy also made its plans to end the year in style, namely in the Andaz Macau, Long Bar and Pony & Plume developments. The party takes place with DJ performances and the promise of unlimited drinks. For those who want something different and, at the same time, themed, there will be a “La Nuit Rouge Countdown Party” at The Ritz-Carlton Bar and Lounge, with French cabaret and live music. Air Supply in Hong Kong Going to Hong Kong to close the year 2025 could also be an option. To begin with, one of the centers of entertainment will be the pedestrian zone on Chater Road, in Central. On the Hong Kong Tourism Board website, it is stated that the public can enjoy “a new format of live music performances combined with light shows”, namely by the band Air Supply, who will perform “a special performance with their timeless classic hits”. The Australian duo, formed in 1975, already has a 50-year career under their belt and has well-known songs such as “All Out of Love”, “Making Love Out of Nothing at All” and “Lost in Love”. This year-end night, Hong Kong artists Jay Fung and Cloud Wan will also perform. There will be no shortage of a children's choir and the Hong Kong Police Band to welcome 2026. The performances start at 11:28 pm. Another countdown is scheduled in the Kowloon area, at WestK Christmas Town 2025. The public can attend concerts by On Chan, Kandy Wong, The Hertz, Nowhere Boys, DJ P-Chef and Hong Kong Arts Without Boundaries Foundation, located at WestK Christmas Lane [Harbourside East Lawn, Art Park], with the Victoria Harbor as a backdrop. The party continues after midnight. Still with remnants of Christmas, the public will be able to see and photograph the tree that is at WestK Christmas Town 2025 and is 12 meters high.

item.title: Game | Morgan Stanley less optimistic about MGM China results
item.description: The investment bank predicts that MGM China's new contract with its parent company to use the MGM brand will have a significant impact on the gaming concessionaire's financial results. The rise in costs for using the MGM brand by the game concessionaire MGM China led investment bank Morgan Stanley to reduce expectations regarding the company's financial results. In a note released to investors, the investment bank now expects the concessionaire's financial results to fall within the market average, whereas previously it expected them to exceed the average. The change in expectations regarding MGM China takes into account the new contract for using the MGM company's brand. According to details released before Christmas, MGM China will now pay 3.5 percent of consolidated monthly net revenues, up from 1.75 percent. This difference means that MGM China will pay practically double to MGM Resorts International, the parent company. Based on this change, Morgan Stanley explains that the new payments should cost the dealership about 7 percent of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) per year. The recently revealed agreement lasts for 20 years, depending on the renewal of the gaming concession after 2030, and foresees a maximum payment of 188.3 million US dollars (1.5 billion patacas) for 2026. However, financial services company CBRE Equity Research believes that the value of MGM China's profits for next year should result in a payment of around US$166 million (1.3 billion patacas). Historical values The payment of around US$166 million for next year contrasts with what has been happening since at least 2023. In that year, the first without movement restrictions after the Covid-19 pandemic, MGM China paid MGM Resorts International around US$55.2 million. The following year, payments rose to US$70.9 million, reflecting the company's improved financial performance. Payments for the current year are not yet known, but by the end of September they totaled US$56.5 million. Taking into account that this rate of profits is maintained, despite the market having expanded in recent months, payments for this year are expected to be around 75.3 million US dollars.

item.title: Research | Prize created for studies on Sino-Portuguese relations
item.description: The “Fundação Jorge Álvares-General Vasco Rocha Vieira-Portugal-China Friendship Award” will award 25 thousand euros per year and aims to recognize institutions that promote initiatives to strengthen rapprochement between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities The Jorge Álvares Foundation launched an annual prize, worth 25 thousand euros, to encourage the study and research of relations between Portugal and China, through Macau, according to the entity's website. With the “Fundação Jorge Álvares-General Vasco Rocha Vieira-Portugal-China Friendship Award”, it also intends to recognize “institutions that promote relevant initiatives in order to reinforce the rapprochement between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities”, it is stated on the foundation's website. “It aims to honor and contribute to perpetuating the memory of the last governor of Macau, founder of the Jorge Álvares Foundation, its curator and first president, who passed away about a year ago”, the current curator, Tiago Vasconcelos, wrote on social media on Monday. The prize will be awarded, alternately, to institutions, in even-numbered years and from 2026, and to research work, in odd-numbered years, this being launched in 2027. In the first case, the award is open to any institution, national or foreign, rewarding “relevant actions that develop or deepen the relationship between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities”, in the fields of Portuguese, Chinese or Patuá culture and languages, science, education, philanthropy, among others. Open investigation With regard to research work, the award “is open to anyone without academic restrictions, nationality or otherwise”, and rewards “the quality of studies and written work on a topic, to be indicated for each edition, within the scope of relations between Portugal and China, particularly through Macau”. “From the signing of the joint declaration to the transfer of the Portuguese administration of Macau” is, according to the regulations, the theme for the first edition of the award in the research category. Vasco Joaquim Rocha Vieira was born on August 16, 1939. He was Chief of the Army General Staff and, inherently, member of the Revolution Council between 1976 and 1978. He served as minister of the Republic of the Azores (1986-1991) and in 1991 was appointed Governor of Macau by the then President of the Portuguese Republic, Mário Soares. He was the 138th and last Portuguese governor of Macau, a position he held until 1999, when the territory was transferred to China.

item.title: Teaching | Around 97% of students use AI tools
item.description: Around 97 percent of secondary school students admitted to having used Artificial Intelligence as a tool to help with their studies. The conclusion is part of a study carried out by the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau, which compared the development of students at local secondary level with students in the Greater Bay Area. Based on the opinion of 2,000 students, the results presented by deputy Lam Lon Wai indicate that 97 percent of students recognized using artificial intelligence. Among these, more than 50 percent stated that artificial intelligence contributed to their obtaining better grades. Half of the respondents also stated that artificial intelligence can generate excessive dependence and that it can affect the development of logical and critical reasoning. Given these results, FAOM recommends that schools customize artificial intelligence tools, to take advantage of the advantages and avoid the negative aspects. The association also considers that it is necessary to change the mentality of educational establishments, with education less focused on obtaining grades to enter the best universities. According to FAOM, the priority should be teaching students to think and develop skills to solve everyday problems.

item.title: ONE | Southern section of the campus in Hengqin will cost 2.38 billion
item.description: The companies Companhia de Construção e Investimento Predial Ming Shun and Jian Tai Construction, from the Huafa group, were chosen to carry out the work, which is scheduled for completion by November 2028. Construction work on the Southern Section of the new University of Macau Campus in Hengqin will cost 2.38 billion patacas (2.086 billion renminbis), according to the award contract. The information was shared by the company within the local educational institution, Guangdong Hengqin UM Higher Education Development, through the portal of the Directorate of Public Supervision and Asset Management Services (DSSGAP). The work was awarded through a public tender and the work will be carried out by the consortium made up of the local company Companhia de Construção e Investimento Predial Ming Shun and Jian Tai Construction, which is based in Zhuhai and is part of the state-owned Huafa group. Since the campus is located in Mainland China, the competition was held in accordance with Chinese legislation and proposals were submitted in renminbis. The consortium made up of Ming Shun and Jian Tai presented the third cheapest proposal of the seven participants in the competition. The award was publicly announced yesterday, despite having been decided on November 11th, establishing that construction of all buildings must begin by tomorrow. Furthermore, the competition requires that some lots and buildings must be ready by February 2028, while the rest are scheduled for completion by November 2028. Participated contest The public tender for the award of the work only included the participation of state-owned companies from Mainland China, some of the largest construction companies in the world. One of the participants was the China Railway Construction Corporation, which presented a proposal worth 2.71 billion patacas (2.38 billion renminbis), the most expensive of all. The same group was involved twice, through the subsidiary China Railway First, and in this case presented the cheapest proposal worth 1.70 billion patacas (1.48 billion renminbi). The tender also included a consortium made up of China Overseas Construction Limited and China State Construction Engineering Corporation, which submitted a proposal of 2.61 billion patacas (2.29 billion renminbi). Zhejiang No. 1 Construction Investment submitted a proposal of 2.53 billion patacas (2.22 billion renminbi), Jiangsu Huajian 2.34 billion patacas (2.05 billion renminbi), while the Beijing Urban Construction Group asked for 2.00 million patacas (1.75 billion renminbi).

item.title: Light Rail | Deputy questions management and connection with buses
item.description: Wong Kit Cheng questioned the Government about the integration of payment methods between the Light Rail and public buses. The deputy also wants to know when the public consultation on the development of the Light Rail network will be launched The development of the Light Rail is the subject of yet another written question by Wong Kit Cheng. In the document, the deputy questions how the planning of this means of transport will be defined without forgetting the connection with the bus network, whose concession contracts expire at the end of 2026. "It is important to provide a convenient user experience [to passengers]. Taking into account that the bus contracts expire at the end of next year, has the Government already started negotiations on the contracts with the two bus companies, in order to integrate a benefits system?", begins by asking the deputy. The question arises within the scope of the promise made by the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, regarding the installation of new payment terminals at Light Rail stations that can be connected to buses, in order to allow different payment methods. More specifically, Wong Kit Cheng would like new bus contracts to include the connection of payment methods taking into account the installation of new terminals. For the deputy, “there is still a large margin for improvement” in the distribution of passengers between the two means of public transport, highlighting that there was a “significant growth” in passengers on the Light Rail, still falling short of “the more than 600 thousand passengers served daily by buses”. Thus, “to achieve the objective of the Light Rail as the main means of transport, and buses as a complement”, Wong Kit Cheng considers that “the authorities need to optimize the passenger experience, especially with regard to resolving long-standing problems, such as Light Rail payment methods, greater coordination of transfers and the resolution of faults, in addition to improving the accessibility of lines and stations”. Ongoing assessments Still regarding the future of the Light Rail, Wong Kit Cheng asked for a “status” of the mid-term assessment that the Executive is carrying out in relation to the execution of the concession contract. “What is the status of these evaluation works? Are there already preliminary results or optimization recommendations, particularly with regard to improving the quality and stability of the service?”, he asked. The deputy also took up another promise made in the last debate on the Lines of Government Action by secretary Raymond Tam, regarding the holding of a public consultation on the study of the Light Rail development strategy. “How will this public consultation be organized”, he asks.

item.title: Hong Kong hosts winter festival until Sunday
item.description: For those who still want to experience the last moments of the season between Christmas and New Year, the neighboring territory hosts the “Hong Kong Winter Fest”, with two events ending next Sunday. A giant Christmas tree in the city center, lots of lights and spaces that spark the imagination is what you can expect from this initiative. One of the spaces is the “Christmas City”, located in Central, which has a 20 meter high Christmas tree and various decorations with toys that make reference to the festive days that have just come to an end. The “Christmas Town” began on November 14th and can be visited until this Sunday. Another attraction of this festival is the “Immersive Light Show”, also in Central. As the name suggests, the public can see a light show, with three-dimensional projections, music and animation, with viewing points in North Square and South Square, Statue Square Gardens. There are shows every 30 minutes between 7:30 am and 11:30 pm. Here, “eight iconic buildings become a giant screen” for this show, with figures such as snowmen, angels or reindeer dancing “among the buildings and trees, creating a rich and dreamy experience that illuminates the festive nights of Hong Kong”, describes the tourism department of the HKSAR Government. The buildings where the light show will be projected are the Bank of China Tower, Hong Kong City Hall High Block, Hong Kong Club, the main building of HSBC and Standard Chartered Bank, among others. Lights until February There is also a third initiative integrated into this winter festival that runs until February 22nd. This is “Starlight Boulevard”, where Chater Road will be adorned with various lights, including a pedestrian crossing and “an impressive centerpiece above the Chater House”. “Visitors can continue their journey under a golden canopy of light to reach Noëlia at LANDMARK, an enchanting large-scale interactive installation for more surprises and Christmas charm”, it is further described on the event page. This area of ​​lights can be visited between Chater Road and Central.

item.title: Analysts estimate that BYD will surpass Tesla in global sales by 2025
item.description: BYD's rapid global expansion and Tesla's regulatory difficulties in the United States and other markets should allow the Chinese manufacturer to lead global sales of all-electric vehicles for the first time in 2025, analysts predict. Both groups are expected to release their annual reports soon, but based on the latest data, BYD's accumulated advantage is such that it seems almost impossible that Tesla has managed to regain ground. By the end of November, BYD had already sold 2,066,002 fully electric vehicles, becoming the first brand to surpass that milestone. Tesla registered 1,217,902 units by the end of September. The North American manufacturer benefited, in the third quarter, from a shopping rush caused by the end of tax incentives in the USA, which led many consumers to anticipate purchasing their vehicles. Tesla's global deliveries rose 7 percent year-on-year to 497,099 vehicles. Analysts predicted a rapid contraction in the following quarter. The consensus of analysts at the financial services company FactSet points to 449 thousand units in the fourth quarter (-9.48 percent compared to the previous year) and a total of 1.65 million vehicles for 2025 (-7.66 percent). This is an annual projection well below the level already reached by BYD until November 30th. German bank Deutsche Bank estimates that Tesla will deliver 405,000 vehicles in the fourth quarter, while analysts at Swiss bank UBS point to 415,000 – both forecasts recently revised downwards. Deutsche Bank highlighted sales below expectations in North America (-33 percent), Europe (-34 percent) and, to a lesser extent, China (-10 percent). Glass half full The TD Cowen bank presents a more optimistic estimate (429 thousand units), but highlights that the quarter was “a little delicate”, due to the end of tax incentives, which made projections difficult, according to analyst Itay Michaeli. “Tesla’s deliveries will show signs of weakness in the fourth quarter,” said the director of Wedbush Securities, Dan Ives. “A total of 420 thousand vehicles would already be enough to show some stability in demand, at a time when the market is focused on the launch of autonomous driving in 2026”, he added. Tesla's sales have been affected by a slower-than-expected electrical transition, increased competition and US President Donald Trump's decisions since returning to power in January. The closeness between Elon Musk and Trump, both during the campaign and after taking office, also affected the brand's image, leading to calls for a boycott. Sales fell sharply, especially in Europe.

item.title: Tourism | Chinese excursionists with a drop of almost 24%
item.description: The Statistics and Census Services Directorate (DSEC) revealed yesterday that the number of day trippers recorded an annual drop of 12.5 percent in November, to a total of 191,000. Noteworthy is the fact that the number of arrivals of visitors on tours from Mainland China, 148,000, fell by 23.7 percent in November, while the number of international visitors on tours, 28,000, grew by 33.8 percent. At the end of November, Macau had a hotel complex with 147 units, just one more compared to November 2024, which provided 45,000 guest rooms, an increase of 3.5 percent. The occupancy rate that month stood at 90.2 percent, with the occupancy rate of 5-star hotels, at 94 percent, rising 2.5 percentage points, while that of 4-star hotels (84.6 percent) and 3-star hotels (84.3 percent) decreased by 1.2 and 3.1 percentage points, respectively.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Xiao Yan (464-549), Emperor Wu of Liang (r.502-549) who greatly promoted Buddhism, perplexed by the decision of the wise Tao Hongjing (456-536) to withdraw from the city in 492, at just thirty-six years old, and go to live far away in the middle of the mountains instead of staying at court, where his wisdom and advice would be abundantly recognized and rewarded, sent him a missive asking him why. According to tradition, the sage, who had dedicated himself to studying the Dao, did not respond to him, but sent him a drawing with two oxen; one free to graze, the other trapped and with a brake. Xiao Yan understood. The fact that Tao Hongjing chose the corpulent animal, which seems to act without effort or haste, to expose his situation, echoes the understanding of the desire for union with nature that certain Chan followers showed with the figure of Laozi (c.371-477 BC) riding an ox (niu) or a buffalo (shuiniu) walking towards the sunset, moving away from civilization, its useless wars and confrontations. Years later, during the Southern Song dynasty (1127-1279), painters used the figure of the patient ox several times, taking advantage of its multiple symbolic meaning. The court painter Yan Ciping (act. 1164-1187) was the author of particularly expressive works in which the figure of the buffalo appears associated with young boys. As in the painting in which the sensation of “docile peace” emerges, as its name ciping implies, and the tactile relationship with the earth, showing two boys sitting, combing each other next to a tree, behind two buffaloes, one large and one small, also sitting, resting (vertical scroll, ink and color on silk, at the Sen-oku Museum, Hakukokan, in Kyoto). In another, made on a fan mounted on an album sheet, a Boy and a Buffalo in an Autumn Landscape (ink and color on silk, 23 x 21 cm, at the Cleveland Museum of Art) one sees, in the fog, as the time of autumnal transformation unfolds, a young man sitting on a buffalo, leading it by the bridle, expressing in the figure of the buffalo the "true me", the boy being The driver, the most fragile-looking Chan practitioner, abandons the world conditioned by illusions. Yan Ciping, like others at the Song dynasty court such as the famous Ma Yuan (c.1160-1225), came from a family of painters who refined their own family style. In certain paintings, such as Inn on a Cliff Covered with Pine Trees (fan mounted as an album sheet, ink and color on silk, 21.4 x 23 cm, at the Metmuseum) it is difficult to distinguish which of the two brothers, sons of the painter Yan Zhong, Ciyu or Ciping is the author. In it, a large part of the painting's space is left blank, suggesting the Chan Buddhist conception that matter emerges from emptiness. Looking at the small painting, the viewer could share the feeling of the object's withdrawal from the work.

item.title: Carlos Morais José
item.description: Our approach to reality, no matter how disciplined and honest the approach to thought, is always ridden by error, especially when there is no alternative to the use of imagination. Geniuses, the ancient Greeks knew about the Earth's sphericity and that's why they attributed a maximum circle to the planet, which they named Ison. Today we call it Ecuador. However, these Hellene geographers considered these regions to be unreachable and uninhabitable. Torrid Zone: there, unbearable heat would boil the oceans, preventing the passage to temperate zones, postulated further south of this line that marked the maximum circle of the sphere. A simple islet, named “das Rolas”, a mere hundred meters from the island of São Tomé, in the Gulf of Guinea, is crossed by this equatorial line. This location of the former Portuguese colony provides it with a type of climate that is only found with such intensity close to the equator: the temperature varies little and, contrary to what the Greeks thought, it does not reach excessive values. Its range is between 20 and 29 degrees Celsius, but the “normal” temperature remains between 23 and 25 degrees. Night, day and throughout the year. In the permanently cloudy sky, the Sun and Moon are rarely seen. And when this happens, they never fail to appear wrapped in veils of clouds, which gives them an unreal character, invoking ancient magic, witnessing moving skies. When, towards the end of the afternoon, the rain extends its reign for more than two or three hours, often presented to plants and animals by a thunderstorm, the light dies and a very dark night reigns over the land and sea. The stars fall beyond the clouds that cover everything. On a night like this, there is no moonlight to illuminate or pierce the clouds. A deep pitch falls on the earth, a darkness that is impenetrable to our eyes. And it was like that, at three in the morning, that I woke up. My eyes opened to an abysmal darkness. Nothing, absolutely nothing could be seen. He knew he had the window open, but not a ray of light deigned to enter the room. I reached out, but the lamp didn't work. The electricity was out again. I waited for some time, hoping to get used to the blackness and discover some shapes in it. In vain. He was immersed in a well of black, warm water, he could feel the humidity on his skin, which had just woken up sweaty from a nightmare. I decided to get up and leave the house, looking for some light. The rain had stopped. Outside, the forest celebrated, hummed, reverberated with sounds. There would be millions of insects, amphibians, vertebrates, all of them nocturnal animals, also immersed in the dark, where they found food, sex and salvation. Life didn't need light. It was heard, deafening. At the edge of that spontaneous excess of trees and plants, nothing could be seen either. Dark, impenetrable dark. Only the sound prevailed, louder and louder, and suggested movements among the trees. That mixture of buzzing, squealing, buzzing, ringing, rales, loudly surrounded my ears, building a helmet that blocked all other senses, including the one that affects me in space. I was dizzy. And in that half-daziness, I groped my way back to the house, to my bed. There was nothing he could do. Forget the coffee, eliminate the possibility of reading or consulting a computer. Lying in the dark as if waking up in a coffin. Our mind cannot handle fear for long. Mostly irrational. As was the case. I can't really talk about fear, fear, but about discomfort, derived from the fragile situation that I attributed to myself. Everything could happen in that dark, and I wouldn't see him. If for some reason you had to leave the room, where would you go, if everything was plunged into darkness? But nothing was happening in the darkness of my room, nor would anything happen that would force me to grope through the pitch black, looking for a light. On the contrary, in that bed I was protected by the dark and if I saw nothing nothing would see me either. This thought provided some comfort. All things considered, that abysmal pitch was strangely comfortable for me. I made it a protective cloak and not a space of threats. And so I remained. The ancient Chinese say that everyone has an excellent place to stay. A place where you can develop and enjoy who you really are. Maybe this dark package is mine. Perhaps in it I can be for myself what I really am, setting aside what surrounds me, instructs and distracts me. I am undoubtedly alone. Without the possibility of communicating with another person or even acting in my surroundings. I'm left. With me. Alone. Isolated. Here I am not the anthropologist, nor the editor, none of my social titles perform any functions. I am not the husband, the friend or the lover. From the outside I only have the language that inhabits me and my brain rebels in search of meaning. And even this takes second place in daydreams whose material seems to emerge from another place, from knowledge not conditioned to a language — an impression of the world and not its explanation. I am a consciousness separated from things, which in the dark finds its most intimate relationship with the universe, of almost dissolution, a chamazita, a fiery being, whose interior insists on shining in the dark night. The universe and me. I'm unique. Nothing can divide me without destroying me. I know I am an individual, because I feel it deeply, with an almost painful acuity, even though neurologists tell me about the Self as an evolutionary fiction, structuralists see me as a product of Culture, psychoanalysts as a Family and Marxists as History. (continued)
