item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis On December 3rd, a White Paper was launched that provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citing police sources, the AFP news agency reports that the attack caused ten deaths. The New South Wales ambulance service confirmed to ABC television that at least 16 people were transported to six hospital centers in the region. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.

item.title: Crime | Government does not release data on suicides and attempts
item.description:
After the Health Services, the Security department also stopped publishing data on suicides and attempts, after ten years of publication. The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Furthermore, during the period in question, 17 cases of pimping or exploitation of prostitution were resolved, with the arrest of 26 suspects. Silence as always Questioned by Lusa during the press conference about the first case to be investigated in Macau within the scope of national security, the secretary made no comments. “The case (…) is being handled by judicial entities and, due to secrecy, it would not be appropriate for the Secretary of Security to comment”, added Chan Tsz King, who was a Public Prosecutor when former deputy Au Kam San was detained. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: Economy | Deputies warn of lack of trust and inequalities
item.description: Despite economic growth throughout this year, Chan Lai Kei and Leong Sun Iok alerted the Government to the problems in community neighborhoods and the need to distribute financial resources more equitably Deputy Chan Lai Kei called on the Government to focus on promoting economic optimism and consumption, considering that in several neighborhoods in Macau the economic situation is worrying, despite macroeconomic growth. The matter was brought to the Legislative Assembly yesterday, an intervention before the agenda in the Plenary. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, the economy is showing a “stable recovery”. Between January and September “the initial value of GDP grew 4.2 percent compared to the same period last year”. It also indicated that the unemployment rate was 2.3 percent between August and October. However, Chan warned that “positive macroeconomic data have not completely eliminated negative indicators”, especially with regard to the lives of the population. Citing a “recent study”, the legislator indicated that there is a weak desire to consume, because “residents’ confidence in increasing income and their satisfaction with their financial situation are still between a low and medium level”. Chan Lai Kei explained that greater consumption abroad contributes to this wave of pessimism, but also the various closures of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): “In view of the stress of consumption abroad, the business environment of SMEs in areas linked to the lives of the population (such as NAPE, Iao Hon and Fai Chi Kei) continues to worsen and the risk of closure remains”, he warned. “These companies generally face the critical challenge of unstable customer sources, high costs and cross-border consumption”, he stressed. Given the scenario outlined, the deputy asked the Executive to create a consumption incentive mechanism similar to discount vouchers, but with a permanent nature, while the “transformation phase of Macau's economic model” lasts, which “reinforces confidence in business”. Improve distribution Deputy Leong Sun Iok also addressed the situation of the economy and pointed out the need to better distribute resources from gambling, the main industry in the territory. The legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau praised the gaming concessionaires for the greater role they have taken in terms of investment for “urban development, tourism promotion and social security”, especially since 2023. However, he regretted that resources are being channeled unequally: "It appears that, currently, both the revenues from the game and the gaming concessionaire companies themselves have invested a lot of resources in social development. But, in general, these resources are dispersed and lack a system and interconnection, therefore, they are unable to achieve maximum social benefit", he pointed out. Leong thus advocated that a greater proportion of the revenue collected by the Administration from gambling be channeled to the Social Security Fund, to pay pensions for the elderly. The deputy also called for the creation of a fund with money from concessionaires to develop the Macao SAR and to ensure that they “better” fulfill the obligations of the gaming law, such as “worker guarantees”, “support for people with disabilities or those rehabilitated”, support for SMEs and “educational, scientific research, environmental protection, cultural and sporting activities and activities of public interest”. Leong Sun Iok also asked for a new portal with public information on concessionaires' expenses with non-gambling activities covered by the concessions' obligations and ended the intervention with a request for caution addressed to the Executive. “Society’s resources do not come easily and are the result of the joint efforts of the Government, companies, the various social sectors and the population in general”, he indicated. "The situation is not always good. I hope the Government makes good use of the resources arising from the social responsibilities of gaming companies, to improve the lives of the population", he highlighted. Minimum Wage | Approved increase of one pataca per hour The increase of one pataca per hour in the minimum wage, from 34 to 35 patacas, was approved yesterday in the Legislative Assembly. With the changes, starting next year, in weekly terms, the salary will go from 1,632 patacas to 1,680 patacas. When the monthly calculations are made, the salary increases from 7,072 patacas to 7,280 patacas, an increase of 2.9 percent that will cover 4.4 percent of Macao SAR workers. Domestic workers are excluded, although the approval of the hiring quota, in the case of non-residents, is normally associated with the requirement of a salary between 3,500 and 4,000 patacas. Budget 2026 | Deputies approve the specialty The Legislative Assembly yesterday approved the budget for next year, which foresees an increase in gaming revenue of 3.5 percent, to 236 billion patacas. The document, which reflects the Executive's economic choices, estimates revenues of 118.8 billion patacas, while expenses are estimated at 113.5 billion patacas. Based on these perspectives, the final balance of the regular budget should be positive at 5.3 billion patacas. However, there is a possibility that the scenario is actually better, given that the Government tends to make default estimates with regard to revenue and expenses. The budget also once again provides for exemption from paying professional tax, up to 30 percent of the annual amount, limited to 144 thousand patacas.

item.title: EU | New target to reduce 90% of pollutants by 2040
item.description: MEPs and countries from the European Union (EU) yesterday reached an agreement on a target to reduce 90 percent of polluting emissions by 2040, with a view to carbon neutrality in 2050, although new forms of flexibility are foreseen. “The co-legislators agreed on a target of a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, compared to 1990 levels, with the aim of achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050”, is announced in a statement released in Brussels. After several hours of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council thus reached, this morning, a provisional political agreement (which will have to be confirmed by both) on an amendment to the EU Climate Law, establishing a new intermediate and binding target for 2040, that of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by 90 percent compared to 1990 levels. Even so, MEPs and countries agreed to introduce new forms of flexibility to meet the 2040 target, “believing that the green transition and European competitiveness must advance hand in hand”, according to the note. Under review Specifically, from 2036 onwards, up to five percentage points of emissions reductions (two more than the Commission's initial proposal) could come from high-quality international carbon credits, compatible with the Paris Agreement. In the case of Portugal, for example, this means that sustainable projects in countries such as Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) can count towards the Portuguese target. “Thanks to Parliament's insistence, additional safeguards were integrated, including the prohibition of financing projects in partner countries that contradict the Union's strategic interests”, highlights the European assembly. It is up to the European Commission to analyze different options for the role of international credits in future EU climate legislation to reach the 2040 target. Furthermore, the community executive will assess progress every two years, taking into account the most recent scientific data, technological advances and the EU's international competitiveness. "The review will analyze the situation of net removals at European level, comparing it with what is necessary to meet the 2040 target, as well as possible implementation difficulties and the potential to strengthen the EU's industrial competitiveness. Trends in energy prices and their impacts on companies and families will also be considered", according to the European Parliament. This will allow Brussels to modify the 2040 target or take additional measures to strengthen the support framework, for example to protect the EU's competitiveness, prosperity and social stability. Parliament will now vote on the informal agreement and the Council will also have to approve it, with the text coming into force 20 days after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. The European Climate Law makes each country's effort to reduce its polluting emissions legally binding.

item.title: Europe | Merz considers aspects of Trump's geostrategy unacceptable
item.description: The head of the German federal government, Friedrich Merz, declared yesterday that there are certain unacceptable points in the document on Defense and geostrategy of the North American Administration led by Donald Trump, from a European perspective. “I don’t see any need for Americans to want to save Democracy in Europe,” he said, on a visit to Rhineland-Palatinate (a southwestern state), which is home to several United States of America (USA) military bases. In a strategic document on US national security, released last week, there is a warning about the danger of “civilizational extinction” in Europe if “current trends” continue. Trump, in the preface, summarizes: “we put America first in everything we do”. “It is more than plausible that, in a few decades at most, the members of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) will become predominantly non-European”, he wrote, adding that “it is legitimate to question whether they will perceive their place in the World or their alliance with the USA, in the same way as those who signed the organization's charter”. The White House regrets European decisions that “undermine political freedom and sovereignty, the migration policies that are transforming the continent [Europe] and creating tensions, as well as the censorship of freedom of expression and the repression of political opposition, the drop in birth rates and the loss of national identities (…)”. Washington expresses the desire for “Europe to remain European, regain its civilizational self-confidence and abandon its fruitless obsession with regulatory suffocation.”

item.title: East Timor | Memories of a man's life reflect the resistance of a people
item.description: The book “Return to Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” recounts the Timorese's testimonies about the years of Timor-Leste's resistance to the Indonesian occupation. The testimony was written in Macau by former resident and university professor Duarte Trigueiros. 50 years after the occupation, the author reminded HM of the work launched in 2022 This year has been marked by the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the independence of many former Portuguese colonies. Timor-Leste went to one of these territories. However, shortly after the unilateral proclamation of independence, on November 28, 1975, there was a period of confrontation that culminated in the Indonesian occupation, on December 7 of the same year. This Sunday marks 50 years since the invasion that marked the fate of the young country. In connection with this date, the book “Regresso a Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” was released in 2022, which reveals the story of the Timorese, who was a student in Macau and a student of the author Duarte Trigueiros, former economist and professor at the University of São José. HM spoke to the author about the reflection of the pain and struggle for self-determination of a people that can be seen in the life of a man and his family. "When I was teaching in Macau, I collected the testimony of this Timorese from Baucau. Domingos Gusmão, knowing that he had taught at the National University of Timor-Leste for several years, told me how he and his family lived through all these terrible events." This is how the book was born, with Trigueiros merely reporting the testimony, later corrected in partnership with Domingos Gusmão. The work only has an online version, but at the time of launch it had the support of Fundação Oriente in printing some copies. Matebian, East Timor Duarte Trigueiros, who lived in Macau for several years, came into contact with Domingos Gusmão during the Festa da Lusofonia, in 2015. "I went to the Timor-Leste tent and he told me that he had interesting things to tell me, but that he couldn't speak Portuguese well, and that he would like to leave his testimony in writing. At one point I proposed asking him questions from his childhood, about life in the village, and thus the book was born, with nine chapters.” The beginning of the work describes, “through the eyes of a child, the day-to-day life of farmers in the Baucau mountains in Timor-Leste, the determination in which they reacted to the invasion of their country in 1975 and the brutal repression that followed”. "The book follows not only his life, but also his family and the few who remained. In the end, there was practically no one left", describes Duarte Trigueiros. According to the work, Domingos Gusmão was born on November 1, 1969 in the village of Uaidora, belonging to the municipality of Baucau, the son of Julião, a farmer, and Juliana, a maid. "But only the place where I was born is correct. The date of birth is nothing more than a conjecture and the names that appear on the certificate as being my parents, Julião and Juliana, are also not those of my real father and mother, but of relatives who adopted me when I was an orphan. In fact, I am the son of Martinho Gusmão, whose code name was 'Maunoco' and he was the chief of the Uaidora village until his death in 1983; and my mother was Ricardina, Martinho Gusmão’s second wife, the one who gave him offspring.” This is how Domingos’ story begins. Going to Baucau The work recounts very difficult years, with thousands of Timorese fleeing into the bush to escape the Indonesians, organizing armed struggle. One of the chapters, highlights Duarte Trigueiros, reports how Domingos and his family "were deported and left without any type of support, without doctors or food. "A huge number of people died at that time, until the beginning of the 80s, and they [Dominicos Gusmão's family], already in the place where they were cultivating the land, began to have fruits from the land, and send children to school. This boy [Domingos Gusmão], during that time, started preparing to go to Baucau to study, something that was not easy, as it was necessary to find a place, and there were many children.” Domingos and Xanana Gusmão It was there that the family decided to leave the village and go to Baucau, finding jobs “at the service of the troops, judges, nurses and doctors”, which gave them their first contacts with the Timorese resistance. "He [Domingos Gusmão] began organizing what they called a clandestine front with his colleagues. The book reports all these adventures that clearly reveal how the resistance worked. This boy then felt the desire to continue his studies and applied to a Catholic seminary", recalled Duarte Trigueiros. The connection to the Catholic religion was not an accident. "The purpose was to go abroad, because the only thing that Indonesians really respected was the Catholic Church, they didn't respect anything else. And he left, spent a number of years training. He was in the Philippines, where he also participated in resistance activities, and returned as a priest, in 2012." Writing this book was important to Domingos Gusmão because he “wanted to mention the names of the [Timorese] commanders of the first phase, when the Indonesian troops entered through Baucau, towards the interior, and there were a large number of resistance commanders who resisted, almost without weapons, and were killed”. “When he spoke to me about this subject, he was very insistent, he told me ‘Write down the name of that commander.’ Everything so that the names would not be forgotten”, he recalled. "What he told me is that nowadays, in Timor-Leste, people are compensating the members of the resistance who are alive, but there are many dead who gave their lives for this and are being forgotten. But this book also talks about everything on a personal level, about what happened to the uncle, how the father died at that stage, thrown to the ground, with a gun butt, with kicks, because he refused to accept an order and they threw him to the ground. He was the head of the village and had to accept the order [of the Indonesians], but he refused”, highlighted Duarte Trigueiros. For the author, the work tells “a truer version” of what the Indonesian occupation was, and very specifically about the experiences of the town of Uaidora and the interior of the country. In the book, you can read Domingos' testimony about this phase of resistance in Baucau, starting in 1986. “I owe my enlistment in the resistance to the clandestine fronts and also to my colleague Domingos de Oliveira. (…) A few weeks later, on the 16th or 17th of September 1991, the centenary of the Dili cathedral was celebrated and young people were invited to participate. 14 left from Baucau. Buses full of teenagers and I was one of them. The next day, during the return trip, FRETILIN flags appeared and we all sang hymns to independence. As we passed through Manatuto, the troops ordered us to stop, but then they told us to continue; and at the entrance to Baucau, before the airport, the road was blocked and we were surrounded by a strong military device. There were only three assault cars!” Gusmão continues his account of this tense moment. "After having cornered us like this, the troops, with the assault vehicles on the right side, occupied the left side. The 14 trucks were lined up with the military device, which had its weapons in position, ready to fire. They were like a very long firing squad. There we stayed, with all those weapons pointed at us, in silence while time passed and nothing happened." Support from Portuguese Duarte Trigueiros and Domingos Gusmão kept in touch, but a stroke took away the Timorese's quality of life. "He hardly responds to my emails. Maybe he has a different outlook on life", confesses the author. Another perspective that the work gives, according to Trigueiros, is the position of the Portuguese authorities during the years of Indonesian occupation, dispelling the idea that there was abandonment after independence. "I simply show what Domingos told me, and he told me that many of the resistance commanders had been Portuguese soldiers and that, therefore, they knew how to use weapons. He also told me that they were extremely patriotic. There is a report that in the 90s they tried to get a satellite phone from Portugal to give to the resistance, and there are references to the support of the Portuguese Embassy in Manila. I think we looked good in the photograph", he concludes. Duarte Trigueiros taught in Timor between 2004 and 2009, where he found higher education very weak. "The students practically didn't know Portuguese and we had to teach in Portuguese. That alone was a huge effort. In general, the students were weak, they were very poorly prepared. The [educational] preparation of the Indonesians had been of a low level, as there was discrimination against students for being Timorese. The book describes this, how only good students had the right to move up, so to speak, and that didn't even mean going to university." Even so, Duarte Trigueiros highlights the training of “a good number of people, engineers, law graduates, economists”. “It took a lot of work and that was the great support that Portugal was able to give”, he added. Today, the former economist says that the Timorese look at the Portuguese with immense gratitude. "It's amazing, because when we go on a street with an Australian, they despise the Australian and don't talk to him, but with the Portuguese they shower him with all kinds of affection. This happens a lot in Timor-Leste", he concluded.

item.title: Weddings | Si Ka Lon wants Macau to be like Las Vegas
item.description: Representative Si Ka Lon argues that Macau should invest in the wedding industry for tourism purposes, similar to what happens in Las Vegas. In an oral question presented to the Government, which will be answered in the Chamber next week, the deputy argues that “‘destination weddings’ is one of the directions for the development of the tourism industry”. Si Ka Lon asks whether local authorities will “take as a reference the successful experiences of Las Vegas or Hong Kong, allowing marriage registration in Macau, regardless of the place of residence or nationality of the bride and groom, with a view to exploring the 'wedding tourism' market”. In the deputy's view, the Executive can “take advantage of Macau's advantages and singularities”, investing in the promotion of “plans for outdoor wedding ceremonies, in order to increase the competitiveness of Macau's wedding tourism products and create a new business card for the city”.

item.title: ONE | Southern section of the campus in Hengqin will cost 2.38 billion
item.description: The companies Companhia de Construção e Investimento Predial Ming Shun and Jian Tai Construction, from the Huafa group, were chosen to carry out the work, which is scheduled for completion by November 2028. Construction work on the Southern Section of the new University of Macau Campus in Hengqin will cost 2.38 billion patacas (2.086 billion renminbis), according to the award contract. The information was shared by the company within the local educational institution, Guangdong Hengqin UM Higher Education Development, through the portal of the Directorate of Public Supervision and Asset Management Services (DSSGAP). The work was awarded through a public tender and the work will be carried out by the consortium made up of the local company Companhia de Construção e Investimento Predial Ming Shun and Jian Tai Construction, which is based in Zhuhai and is part of the state-owned Huafa group. Since the campus is located in Mainland China, the competition was held in accordance with Chinese legislation and proposals were submitted in renminbis. The consortium made up of Ming Shun and Jian Tai presented the third cheapest proposal of the seven participants in the competition. The award was publicly announced yesterday, despite having been decided on November 11th, establishing that construction of all buildings must begin by tomorrow. Furthermore, the competition requires that some lots and buildings must be ready by February 2028, while the rest are scheduled for completion by November 2028. Participated contest The public tender for the award of the work only included the participation of state-owned companies from Mainland China, some of the largest construction companies in the world. One of the participants was the China Railway Construction Corporation, which presented a proposal worth 2.71 billion patacas (2.38 billion renminbis), the most expensive of all. The same group was involved twice, through the subsidiary China Railway First, and in this case presented the cheapest proposal worth 1.70 billion patacas (1.48 billion renminbi). The tender also included a consortium made up of China Overseas Construction Limited and China State Construction Engineering Corporation, which submitted a proposal of 2.61 billion patacas (2.29 billion renminbi). Zhejiang No. 1 Construction Investment submitted a proposal of 2.53 billion patacas (2.22 billion renminbi), Jiangsu Huajian 2.34 billion patacas (2.05 billion renminbi), while the Beijing Urban Construction Group asked for 2.00 million patacas (1.75 billion renminbi).

item.title: Land | Coutinho calls for greater transparency
item.description: Deputy José Pereira Coutinho believes that more transparency is needed in the dissemination of information about land controlled by the Macao SAR. The matter will be addressed in an oral questioning in the Legislative Assembly (AL), between the 6th and 7th of January. In the interpellation, which was published yesterday on the AL portal, the deputy linked to the Macau Public Service Workers' Association defended greater dissemination of information from Government portals. Furthermore, the deputy questions what the Executive's plans are to deal with the issue of outstanding land. In 2016, the then Chief Executive, Fernando Chui Sai, admitted that the Government had to allocate more than 88 thousand square meters in land that had been withdrawn from private ownership to be used for public purposes.

item.title: Light Rail | Deputy questions management and connection with buses
item.description: Wong Kit Cheng questioned the Government about the integration of payment methods between the Light Rail and public buses. The deputy also wants to know when the public consultation on the development of the Light Rail network will be launched The development of the Light Rail is the subject of yet another written question by Wong Kit Cheng. In the document, the deputy questions how the planning of this means of transport will be defined without forgetting the connection with the bus network, whose concession contracts expire at the end of 2026. "It is important to provide a convenient user experience [to passengers]. Taking into account that the bus contracts expire at the end of next year, has the Government already started negotiations on the contracts with the two bus companies, in order to integrate a benefits system?", begins by asking the deputy. The question arises within the scope of the promise made by the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, regarding the installation of new payment terminals at Light Rail stations that can be connected to buses, in order to allow different payment methods. More specifically, Wong Kit Cheng would like new bus contracts to include the connection of payment methods taking into account the installation of new terminals. For the deputy, “there is still a large margin for improvement” in the distribution of passengers between the two means of public transport, highlighting that there was a “significant growth” in passengers on the Light Rail, still falling short of “the more than 600 thousand passengers served daily by buses”. Thus, “to achieve the objective of the Light Rail as the main means of transport, and buses as a complement”, Wong Kit Cheng considers that “the authorities need to optimize the passenger experience, especially with regard to resolving long-standing problems, such as Light Rail payment methods, greater coordination of transfers and the resolution of faults, in addition to improving the accessibility of lines and stations”. Ongoing assessments Still regarding the future of the Light Rail, Wong Kit Cheng asked for a “status” of the mid-term assessment that the Executive is carrying out in relation to the execution of the concession contract. “What is the status of these evaluation works? Are there already preliminary results or optimization recommendations, particularly with regard to improving the quality and stability of the service?”, he asked. The deputy also took up another promise made in the last debate on the Lines of Government Action by secretary Raymond Tam, regarding the holding of a public consultation on the study of the Light Rail development strategy. “How will this public consultation be organized”, he asks.

item.title: Nam Van | Temporary Landfill will cost almost 12 million patacas
item.description: The work is part of a plan presented in August to provisionally use lots A3, A4 and A9 at Lake Nam Van. The plan includes the construction of a new parking zone in the city center The construction work on the embankment and temporary foundations of lot A4 at Nam Van Lake will cost 11.82 million patacas. The work was awarded to the Tak Fat Kin Ip Construction and Engineering Works Company and aims to allow the provisional use of the land, according to the Public Works Services Directorate (DSOP) portal. The work was awarded through a consultation procedure by DSOP with some construction companies, which resulted in the presentation of six proposals, with prices varying between 10.68 million patacas and 14.73 million patacas. All of them committed to completing the works within 180 days. According to DSOP, "currently, lot A4 is an abandoned construction site", despite having an area of ​​1,500 square meters" and being located in a central area of ​​the city. The work required of Tak Fat Kin Ip aims to create the conditions for "the next construction of temporary public spaces", as well as "completely resolve any emerging risks of accumulation of stagnant water" in the existing buildings on lot A4. Take advantage The use of the Nam Van Lake plot is part of a broader Government plan, presented in August this year, when the objective was set to “use, in the short term, the three plots of land A3, A4 and A9 at Nam Van Lake for the creation of temporary public spaces”. The Executive intends to “meet residents' reasonable expectations regarding the optimal use of land and, at the same time, improve the urban landscape of the city center, enriching the experience of Macau as a tourist city”. This option takes into account that the land is located close to some of the city's most popular tourist attractions. Furthermore, the land is located in a commercial area, which means that during holidays the traffic is “very intense” and that during rush hours “crowd control measures are implemented”. In August, DSOP also committed to carrying out “temporary works that include the construction of a temporary walkway along the lake on lot A9, which will connect with the arcades of the surrounding buildings”. This connection will allow you to walk directly between the Lake View Mansion and Nam Van Peninsula buildings along the lakeshore, without the current need to bypass lot A9. In lots A3 and A4, between the Hotel Grand Emperor buildings and the FIT Center of Macau, a temporary parking lot will be built.

item.title: Leong Pou OU wants more protection for self-employed workers
item.description: Deputy Leong Pou U believes that the Government should create new legislation to guarantee more protection for self-employed workers. The matter appears in an oral interpellation that was released yesterday by the legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau. According to the deputy, the most recent developments in the productive forces will give rise to “new forms of production relations and labor relations”. However, Leong Pou U warns that the new relationships will be more “flexible” and unstable and that they “differ significantly from traditional models that feature fixed working hours, fixed workplaces and stable employment relationships”. Despite the new models, the deputy argues that it is necessary to protect “workers' rights in forms of employment and create a legal environment favorable to the development of new quality productive forces”. “Will the authorities carry out a systematic review and amendment of labor laws and regulations in response to the emergence of new forms of employment, thus reinforcing the safeguard of workers’ rights in these new regimes?”, he asks. Gray areas Regarding new forms of work, Leong Pou U also indicates that they often take place outside the traditional licenses granted by bodies such as the Institute for Municipal Affairs. Therefore, Leong asks how the authorities will adapt to the change. The deputy exemplified the new paradigm with the fine imposed on a young man who charged money for photographs near the Ruins of São Paulo. “Recently, a resident who provided paid photography services near the Ruins of São Paulo was fined by the IAM for alleged violations of the street vendor regulations”, he indicates. “I would like to ask the secretary how the rights and interests of freelancers or people with multiple jobs will be strengthened in the future in order to promote high-quality employment for residents, especially young people,” he asked.

item.title: Aviation | Deputy asks if there will be support for new companies
item.description: In February, the new aviation law comes into force, ending Air Macau's monopoly. Lam Lon Wai wants to know how the Government will chart the future development of the civil aviation industry Deputy Lam Lon Wai asked the Government if there are plans to support airlines to establish themselves in Macau. The matter will be addressed in the Legislative Assembly, in an oral intervention, which was announced yesterday by the legislator. In the text, Lam Lon Wai begins by regretting that “for many years, Macau only had one local airline” which meant that “the overall size of the market continues to be relatively small”. The legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) points out that the new law that ends Air Macau's monopoly is causing the aviation market to enter “a new phase of development”. In this sense, the deputy wants to know how the authorities will “proactively take advantage of new opportunities” to “attract more financially solid aviation companies to establish companies or local branches in Macau”. As part of the strategy, Lam Lon Wai asked whether the Government will launch measures such as “air rights exploitation agreements”, “expansion of airport facilities” or “staff training initiatives” to “boost the Macau aviation market into a new phase of diversification and regional cooperation”. More companies The new aviation law will come into force in February next year, and the deputy recalls that “one of the main objectives of the legislation is to allow the creation of local airlines, thus promoting a more autonomous civil aviation system for Macau”. Lam Lon Wai therefore wants to know whether the entry into force of the new legislation will be seen as an opportunity to reconsider aviation agreements with different jurisdictions. “Will the authorities review all air service agreements signed with various countries and formulate incentive policies to attract foreign carriers, thus reinforcing Macau’s advantages as a transit hub?”, he asked. The deputy also indicates that Macau can be a hub for regional aviation. “If efforts in the future include greater regional collaboration between airports with the flexible use of air rights, Macau has the potential to evolve and transform into a center for air and logistics connections in the Greater Bay Area”, he pointed out. However, to implement this strategy, the deputy indicated that it is important that the Hengqin Cargo Terminal for Macau International Airport comes into operation in 2027.

item.title: It’s good for Ukraine
item.description: I do not discuss the past or the personality of Vladimir Putin. I do not discuss Russia's expansionist policy. I discuss the politics of Portugal and the European Union. In Portugal there are around four million citizens who live on the edge of poverty. There are thousands of Portuguese people with poor pensions. There are elderly people living alone without any medical or social support. There are homes that are human rubbish bins. There are not enough public daycare centers for Portuguese children. There are hundreds of slums. There are hundreds of homeless people, cold and hungry, all over the cities. There are buildings owned by the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Lisboa, with more than five floors, completely abandoned and in ruins in a country where there is no social housing for young people, the elderly, the disabled and families who survive by having to choose whether to purchase food or medicine. There are young people who, at the age of 40, still live in their parents' homes because they are unable to rent or buy a house, much less live in a civil union with a partner and have children. There is a Ministry of Defense that announces the future purchase of war material and aircraft worth billions of euros when public hospitals have closed emergency rooms and future mothers are giving birth at home, in ambulances, in private cars or on the street. There are blind and disabled people who cannot use certain Lisbon Metro stations because there are no elevators or escalators. There are prison establishments where inmates are provided with a type of food that even dogs reject. There are students who finish secondary school and go to work in a restaurant or in the construction industry because their parents do not have money to pay for tuition fees and university supplies. There are beggars asking for money every day in every city in the country. There are more than 100,000 poor people who have been suspended from a miserable monthly income subsidy of 200 euros. item.title: Policies for attracting investment, valuation services and inspection of the Science and Technology Park
item.description: The Science and Technology Park is linked to the future of Macau Deputies Lei Wun Kong and Wong Ka Lon Macau's economy is overly dependent on gaming revenue, but with the emergence of artificial intelligence in the industry, young people are no longer enthusiastic about offline gaming. With the passage of time, changes in the external situation and other factors, gaming revenues may be unstable and affected. Therefore, the Science and Technology Park project is the key to adequate diversification of the economy. Question: Create and improve policies for attracting investment and post-investment services and supervision of the said Park Nowadays, businesspeople are more conservative. To efficiently promote the Park project in question, the Government must take the initiative to attract investments and provide enhancement services. Despite the efforts made by public services, namely the Secretariat for Economy and Finance and its subordinate services, it is necessary to create and improve policies for attracting investment, post-investment services and supervision of the aforementioned Park. Model: Taking the experiences of model cities in Mainland China as a reference In recent years, model cities in Mainland China have defined five models for attracting investment. The first is through capital, “funds + industries”, the government creates an industrial fund to promote the implementation of projects, such as the Suzhou biotechnology industry. The second is through a cluster “led by dominant industries”, that is, creating an industrial cluster around dominant companies, for example, in Shenzhen it is Huawei that drives the respective industries. The third is based on “demand-driven supply”, that is, exploring application scenarios to attract technology companies, for example, the company Hangzhou City Brain integrated Alibaba Cloud to develop the application of AI. The fourth is based on “intelligent data matching” to capture digital investments, that is, the creation of big-data to accurately define target companies, such as the “digital investment capture” system in Guangzhou. The fifth is based on “interregional cooperation”, that is, it transcends the delimitation of administrative regions, such as the Shenzhen-Shantou cooperation zone, led by Shenzhen. Strategy: Develop differentiated policies according to the reality of Macau Macau, as a micro-economy, in addition to the lack of human resources and land, does not have dominant companies, so it is difficult to create an industrial cluster. Therefore, we must maximize our unique advantages (such as the “one country, two systems” principle, free port, autonomous customs zone, simple tax regime, connection platform with Portuguese-speaking countries and the European legal system, and transform all of this into concrete and attractive points and services for attracting investment), and transform Macau into a platform for interconnection between scientific and technological companies from China and the PLP. Therefore, we can take the following measures: 1) based on the performance agreement, promote industrial orientation through strategic social participation of the industrial fund, in order to achieve the leverage effect of capital with controlled risk; 2) promote cooperation in attracting inter-regional investment, clearly define the division of labor with Henqin and ensure investment effectiveness; 3) capture local and international talent to attract investments, granting qualified candidates non-permanent resident status; 4) create a large bank to attract investments, etc. At this time, it is necessary for the Government to implement policies to attract investment through legal incentives aimed at businesspeople who want to enter the park. The investment capture model, operational management and preferential policies, among other key steps, must be clarified. The capture of high-level investments must be ensured and the management process detailed a posteriori, in order to highlight the change in the role of the Government, from manager to service provider, achieving the articulation of these measures with the 15th Five-Year Plan of the Country and the needs and advantages of Macau. Guarantee: Improvement of value-added services and quantitative supervision When attracting investments, star cities in Mainland China, in addition to providing value-added services to companies for investment, should facilitate the development of these companies, guiding them towards their continuous growth. Once the process of attracting investments is completed, the phase of monitoring the production value and investment intensity per acre of land follows, which will be used as a basis for determining the value of subsidies and benefits granted by the respective governments. Although it is difficult for Macau to adopt the quantification model per acre of land, it can carry out an appropriate quantification, taking into account its own needs. For example, taking as quantitative indicators the intensity of employment, the size of investment and possible entry into the capital market. Thus, these values ​​determine the financial support that is granted, as well as tax benefits and other incentive measures. At the same time, as the area of ​​the scientific and technological park and human resources are limited, it is necessary to better define the proportion of each sector, but the blind search for a “large and complete” scope must be avoided. Furthermore, policies should be oriented towards Hengqin-Macao cooperation, cooperation inside and outside the park, and industry-academia-research purposes. In short, the Government must create an improved system of value-added services and quantitative supervision for attracting investments, in order to achieve advances in several dimensions, namely in “industrial positioning, excellent complementary policies, deep synergy between Macau and Hengqin, the ecosphere of the investment capture process, and the management of business confidence”.

item.title: Is erotic audio storytelling replacing video?
item.description: Eroticism is gaining a new voice — literally. While video dominated the mainstream sexual imagination for decades, today audio narrative sexual fantasy is experiencing a moment of great popularity: erotic podcasts, apps that tell sensual stories and audiobooks capable of provoking arousal. It is a form of eroticism that appeals to imagination, intimacy and personal experience in a way that visual pornography rarely does. The audio format works in a radically different way than video. When we watch videos, we receive a ready-made image, a visual script that dictates what should excite us. They are bodies with specific characteristics, many of them with surgical alterations that follow fashions of what is supposed to be sensual or exciting. The audio, on the other hand, works as a suggestion: we are the ones who build the setting, the characters and the chemistry. The narrative comes into play as a kind of trigger — a trigger that allows the imagination to do what it does best: create our own erotic fantasy. When we listen to an erotic audio story, our brains are not just processing external stimuli; they are actively collaborating with the narrative, filling spaces, generating unique images and sensations. This participation can heighten the erotic response in a way that is different from the more passive experience of watching a screen. These audio stories manage to center the experience on the listener, often placing them in the main role of the fantasy and creating a sense of connection and intimacy that is difficult to replicate on video. The growing popularity of audio erotica appears to respond to emotional and sexual needs that many people feel are not addressed by traditional forms of pornography. With the narrative, the listener stops being just a consumer and becomes involved in a process of co-creation of the erotic. Apps like Quinn or Dipsea produce narrated stories, often focused on the listener's perspective — with voices, ambient sound and an engaging narrative — rather than explicit images. It is not only the nature of eroticism that explains this growing popularity, but also the audience for whom these stories are created. Many of these apps and podcasts are designed by women and for women, or for queer people. Pornography, historically associated with the male gaze and desire (with some exceptions), tends to leave out other equally relevant imaginaries. Erotic audio narratives have explored precisely these territories traditionally considered more “feminine”: consent, emotion, vulnerability and female pleasure. Here, the focus on history and anticipation builds a form of eroticism that privileges connection — without ever giving up on excitement. The success of these apps, podcasts and audio stories suggests that many people are looking for stories that include them and respect their rhythms and desires, especially those who have never recognized themselves in mainstream erotica. The focus on emotional connection, the simple fact that someone whispers sensual words directly into the headphones, creates an intimate and almost confidential experience. This emotional rarity — feeling heard, desired and imagined in the erotic universe — makes audio simultaneously exciting, liberating and safe. The return to voice can, therefore, be more than a passing fad. It may be a reflection of how we want to experience eroticism today: not as distant spectators, but as active participants in our own erotic co-creation.

item.title: Lessons from 2025 for the Decade
item.description: (Continuation of the article published on December 11) In the security sector, the world will face complex challenges. Terrorism could take on new forms, using digital technologies and artificial intelligence. Cybersecurity will become a priority, with digital attacks on critical systems posing significant risks. It is estimated that by 2030 the global costs of cyber attacks could exceed US$10 billion annually. On a military level, geopolitical tensions between the United States and China could intensify. The Middle East will continue to be a focus of instability. Between 2026 and 2030, social and cultural scenarios will assume a determining role in shaping the global future. International migration will continue to be one of the most striking phenomena, driven by armed conflicts, economic inequalities and climate change. It is estimated that hundreds of millions of people may be in a situation of international or internal mobility, either in search of better living conditions or out of need for survival. Europe will face migratory pressures from Africa and the Middle East, with hundreds of thousands of people seeking refuge in countries such as Italy, Greece, Spain and Germany. This flow will require more robust integration policies, but it could also generate social and political tensions, fueling populist and nationalist discourses. In the United States, immigration will continue to be a central issue, with restrictive policies causing social tensions and protests, but also with the need for labor in sectors such as agriculture, construction and services. In Latin America, internal migration will intensify due to extreme climatic phenomena, such as floods and droughts, forcing millions of people to move from rural areas to cities. In Africa, desertification and armed conflicts in the Sahel could displace more than 20 million people, creating large-scale humanitarian crises. Urbanization will be another central phenomenon. By 2030, more than 65% of the world's population will live in urban areas, with megacities growing rapidly. Cities such as Lagos, Kinshasa, Mumbai, São Paulo and Jakarta could exceed 30 million inhabitants, facing challenges in infrastructure, housing, transport and sanitation. Accelerated urbanization will bring opportunities for economic and cultural dynamism, but also risks of inequality and social exclusion. Cities will need to invest in sustainable solutions, such as efficient public transport, affordable housing and waste management. The digitalization of cities, using smart technologies, can improve the quality of life, but will require inclusion policies to prevent vulnerable populations from being excluded. Demographic transformations will be equally decisive. Population aging in Europe, Japan and South Korea will require health and long-term care policies, with an impact on pension systems and fiscal sustainability. It is estimated that, by 2030, more than 25% of Europe's population will be over 65 years old, creating productivity and financing challenges for social systems. In contrast, Africa and parts of Asia will have growing young populations, with millions of people entering the job market. This phenomenon could be an opportunity for economic dynamism, but also a risk of instability if sufficient jobs are not created. India, for example, will have more than 1.5 billion inhabitants in 2030, with a young population that could drive growth, but will require massive investments in education and training. China will face the challenge of an aging population, with more than 400 million people over the age of 60 in 2030, which could limit economic dynamism and increase pressure on healthcare and pension systems. Cultural scenarios will also transform. Digital globalization will continue to spread cultural values ​​and practices, but also generate tensions between local traditions and external influences. Music, cinema and literature will circulate increasingly intensely, creating a hybrid global culture. However, movements asserting identity and valuing local cultures will gain strength, seeking to preserve traditions and resist cultural homogenization. Cultural diversity will be both a wealth and a challenge, requiring policies of inclusion and respect for difference. Migration, urbanization and demographic transformations will interact with environmental and technological phenomena. Cities will have to adapt to extreme weather phenomena, such as floods and heat waves, which will affect millions of people. Climate migration will become a reality, with entire populations moving due to rising sea levels and desertification. Accelerated urbanization will require technological solutions, such as smart cities and sustainable infrastructure, but also social policies to ensure inclusion. Demographic transformations will create new balances of power, with Africa and Asia gaining demographic and economic weight, while Europe and Japan will face aging challenges. In summary, the period between 2025 and 2030 can be described as a critical transition phase, in which the events of 2025 acted as catalysts for structural changes that manifested themselves in different dimensions. The global economy entered a cycle of moderate recovery, but with persistent risks. International politics was marked by polarization and geopolitical tensions, with the United States and China competing for technological and industrial leadership, and the Middle East remaining a focus of instability. The environment has revealed the urgency of the energy transition and climate adaptation, with extreme phenomena affecting millions of people. Technology has transformed economies and societies, creating opportunities and risks. Education and health required inclusive and innovative policies. Security has become a priority, with cyberattacks and digital terrorism posing significant risks. The social and cultural scenarios revealed the importance of migration, urbanization and demographic transformations. The future will depend on the ability to articulate national interests with collective responsibilities, building a balance between competitiveness and solidarity. If countries are able to invest in responsible innovation, inclusive education and energy sustainability, it will be possible to build a fairer, sustainable and inclusive future. Otherwise, the risk of prolonged stagnation and worsening inequalities will remain high. The period between 2025 and 2030 will therefore remain a decisive moment, in which humanity was called to choose between cooperation and fragmentation, between the courage to move forward and the risk of remaining a prisoner of its own contradictions.

item.title: New Year's Eve | Street parties and concerts to end 2025
item.description: Macau and Hong Kong will be in full swing tonight with celebrations that will welcome 2026. From free concerts next to Praça do Lago Sai Van and at the Taipa Houses-Museum, to shows at Cotai and Mariza's performance at the Macau Cultural Center, there is no shortage of options for all tastes The end of 2025 is here, and if some opt for a more homely celebration, there will be many people willing to go out and have fun in the company of friends and with lots of music in the mix. With paid and free options, Macau and Hong Kong offer a range of options for various tastes. One of the initiatives comes from the Cultural Institute (IC) and is already a tradition. The end of 2025 is celebrated next to Praça do Lago Sai Van from 10pm, and from 9pm at the Taipa Houses-Museum, with the “New Year’s Eve Concert – Macau 2025” and the “New Year’s Eve Party – Taipa 2025”. Various singers and musical groups perform at the concert on the peninsula side, between 10pm and 12:10am, including Hong Kong singer Panther Chan and rock band Dear Jane. There is also a cast of local artists such as Soler, Filipe Tou, KC Ao Ieong, winifai, Jenny, thetiredeyes and Initial B, “who will alternate [performances] to present a diverse range of music to celebrate a dazzling New Year's Eve”, describes the IC. In the case of this performance at Praça do Lago Sai Van, the stage floor stands out, which will feature “an electronic screen combined with lighting and visual effects, providing a totally new visual experience”. “The entire performance will be presented in a theatrical format adapted to each session, which conveys, through narratives, the wishes for the coming year and reflects the exciting facets of the city”, adds the IC. Regarding the concerts at the Taipa Houses-Museum, the theme will be “Multicultural Integration”, with the public being able to see performances by FIDA, Tuna Macaense, Bossa Eva and João Gomes & Band and Karen Tong, a singer from Hong Kong. In addition, there will be performances by the Bollywood Dreams Group, by Victor Kumar, and the Filipino dance groups of the Macau Bisdak Association and Burmese and Vietnamese dance groups from Macau. The poster is completed with magic presentations by magician Jason Fong. From 8:30 pm and until 11:30 pm, there will be cultural exhibitors from local communities in the Philippines, India, Myanmar and Vietnam, who aim to promote the cuisine and culture of their countries. Mariza at CCM Another great highlight to end the year is the performance by fado singer Mariza at the Macau Cultural Center (CCM) from 8pm, alongside the Macau Orchestra. “Mariza, the Queen of Fado and the Macau Orchestra (OM)” is the name given to the concert where the fado singer will perform, “with her deeply emotional voice, a selection of iconic fados, providing the public with a musical experience that transcends genres and spatial and temporal boundaries”. The Portuguese is described “as one of the biggest international Fado stars, being recognized for her own musical style, which incorporates elements of soul, jazz and gospel”. Looking at Cotai, gaming operators bet heavily on year-end programs. The Venetian Arena concert hall hosts the third and final in a series of concerts by Jason Zhang, which began on Monday. Tickets range from MOP680 to MOP2,580 for VIP seats. Jason Zhang Jie was born in 1982 in China and debuted in the “My Show” competition in 2004, becoming the winner, which gave him access to a contract with Universal Music China. At the end of 2023, he already had 15 albums recorded and a total of 87 concerts in his career. Still at the Venetian, as well as at The Parisian Macao and The Londoner, there will be fireworks, with the traditional countdown until 2026. The “Sands New Year’s Eve Countdown Extravaganza” event starts with music at 9:30 pm. Like Sands China, the gaming operator Galaxy also made its plans to end the year in style, namely in the Andaz Macau, Long Bar and Pony & Plume developments. The party takes place with DJ performances and the promise of unlimited drinks. For those who want something different and, at the same time, themed, there will be a “La Nuit Rouge Countdown Party” at The Ritz-Carlton Bar and Lounge, with French cabaret and live music. Air Supply in Hong Kong Going to Hong Kong to close the year 2025 could also be an option. To begin with, one of the centers of entertainment will be the pedestrian zone on Chater Road, in Central. On the Hong Kong Tourism Board website, it is stated that the public can enjoy “a new format of live music performances combined with light shows”, namely by the band Air Supply, who will perform “a special performance with their timeless classic hits”. The Australian duo, formed in 1975, already has a 50-year career under their belt and has well-known songs such as “All Out of Love”, “Making Love Out of Nothing at All” and “Lost in Love”. This year-end night, Hong Kong artists Jay Fung and Cloud Wan will also perform. There will be no shortage of a children's choir and the Hong Kong Police Band to welcome 2026. The performances start at 11:28 pm. Another countdown is scheduled in the Kowloon area, at WestK Christmas Town 2025. The public can attend concerts by On Chan, Kandy Wong, The Hertz, Nowhere Boys, DJ P-Chef and Hong Kong Arts Without Boundaries Foundation, located at WestK Christmas Lane [Harbourside East Lawn, Art Park], with the Victoria Harbor as a backdrop. The party continues after midnight. Still with remnants of Christmas, the public will be able to see and photograph the tree that is at WestK Christmas Town 2025 and is 12 meters high.

item.title: Hong Kong hosts winter festival until Sunday
item.description: For those who still want to experience the last moments of the season between Christmas and New Year, the neighboring territory hosts the “Hong Kong Winter Fest”, with two events ending next Sunday. A giant Christmas tree in the city center, lots of lights and spaces that spark the imagination is what you can expect from this initiative. One of the spaces is the “Christmas City”, located in Central, which has a 20 meter high Christmas tree and various decorations with toys that make reference to the festive days that have just come to an end. The “Christmas Town” began on November 14th and can be visited until this Sunday. Another attraction of this festival is the “Immersive Light Show”, also in Central. As the name suggests, the public can see a light show, with three-dimensional projections, music and animation, with viewing points in North Square and South Square, Statue Square Gardens. There are shows every 30 minutes between 7:30 am and 11:30 pm. Here, “eight iconic buildings become a giant screen” for this show, with figures such as snowmen, angels or reindeer dancing “among the buildings and trees, creating a rich and dreamy experience that illuminates the festive nights of Hong Kong”, describes the tourism department of the HKSAR Government. The buildings where the light show will be projected are the Bank of China Tower, Hong Kong City Hall High Block, Hong Kong Club, the main building of HSBC and Standard Chartered Bank, among others. Lights until February There is also a third initiative integrated into this winter festival that runs until February 22nd. This is “Starlight Boulevard”, where Chater Road will be adorned with various lights, including a pedestrian crossing and “an impressive centerpiece above the Chater House”. “Visitors can continue their journey under a golden canopy of light to reach Noëlia at LANDMARK, an enchanting large-scale interactive installation for more surprises and Christmas charm”, it is further described on the event page. This area of ​​lights can be visited between Chater Road and Central.

item.title: CCM | “The Journey of a Soloist”, a concert to see and hear today
item.description: Studio II of the Macau Cultural Center today hosts a classical music show led by the Macau Chinese Orchestra. “Chinese Music 360º: The Journey of a Soloist” features Kin Szeto, a young maestro from Hong Kong A sound experience, immersion of the senses and a way to spend the last days of the year surrounded by music: all the arguments are good for attending today, in Studio II of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM), the concert led by the Macau Chinese Orchestra (OCM). “Chinese Music 360º: The Journey of a Soloist” starts at 7:45 pm and features the young Hong Kong maestro Kin Szeto.
