According to the concert synopsis, this is a show that promises to break “with the traditional concert format, offering a unique and immersive experience”, “a new way of listening to Chinese music: being inside the orchestra”, reads the show poster, whose tickets cost 150 patacas. “In addition to presenting classic works of Chinese music, the audience is provided with an immersive 360-degree sound effect, allowing them to feel the dialogue and resonance between the instruments through innovative arrangements”, adds the OCM presentation. The OCM also describes that the public can “be immersed in the vastness of Chinese music”, with the promise that Kin Szeto, “winner of international orchestra conducting competitions, will lead the orchestra with his technical mastery and energetic style, exploring all the richness of Chinese music”. A long career Kin Szeto received his doctorate in Musical Arts and orchestral conducting at the University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music, under the supervision of Mark Gibson, and a scholarship that covered his entire studies. Previously, he completed a master's degree in New York, at Ithaca College. The young man from Hong Kong won the 2022 Orchestra Conductors Competition prize in Romania, having made his European debut with the Brasov Philharmonic Orchestra. In the United States, Kin Szeto held various musical positions, such as guest and assistant conductor and also musical director. Furthermore, the maestro is a performer of the erhu, a traditional Chinese music instrument. He was a musician at the Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra between 2011 and 2016, and later served as conductor of the orchestra. More music in January Also noteworthy is the holding of a concert led by OCM in January, on the 16th, starting at 7:45 pm. It is titled “Dawn Breaks” and features Liao Yuan-Yu as conductor and musicians Lin Jie, performer of ruan, a traditional Chinese instrument; and also Hou Guangyu, who will be on stage playing a dizi. The program includes compositions such as “Bamboo Reverie”, by Li Jiaying, played by the orchestra together with the dizi; “Formation Break: Contempo”, by JunYi Chow; and also “Macau Impressions”, a work commissioned and composed by Zhao Jiping. According to the concert synopsis, the OCM maestro will “lead the audience through an exciting artistic journey, from the first flashes of inspiration”. “The concert will feature Hou Guangyu, renowned bamboo flutist, who will perform the flute concerto ‘Bamboo Reverie’. Lin Jie, head of the Orchestra’s ruan section, will perform, together with the Orchestra, ‘Ode to the Sun’, a work that reveals the strength of joy and encouragement”, it reads.

item.title: Death | French actress Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
item.description: Brigitte Bardot, one of the biggest stars in world cinema, passed away yesterday at the age of 91. The actress had been admitted to the hospital in the city of Toulon, in the south of France, since November. In a statement, the Brigitte Bardot Foundation announced her death with “immense sadness”, describing her as a “world-renowned actress and singer, who chose to abandon her prestigious career to dedicate her life and energy to animal welfare and her foundation”. Known for her enormous impact on cinema in the 1950s, «BB», as she was widely called in France, was an essential ingredient of French culture and quickly became an icon after her first role in Le Trou Normand (1952). Two more films followed in 1952, when she married director Roger Vadim. A year later, Bardot conquered Hollywood and the United States, and her popularity as one of the sexiest women in the world was firmly established. Brigitte Bardot continued to act in a total of 28 films over two decades and became a symbol of women's sexual liberation. However, ruthlessly “marketed” as a sexual and hedonistic symbol, Bardot ended up succumbing to the frustration of not being taken seriously as an actress and abandoned her career to dedicate herself to campaigns for animal welfare.

item.title: Money exchange | Raid targets 60 million Hong Kong dollar deal
item.description: The Judiciary Police (PJ) announced the arrest of two women for allegedly being involved in illegal exchanges of money for gambling at a casino in Cotai. According to police estimates, the business operating in a jewelry store had a turnover of more than 60 million Hong Kong dollars, with profits being 1 million Hong Kong dollars. The detainees are a 36-year-old local resident and a 27-year-old woman from Mainland China. Both performed sales roles in the commercial space. At yesterday's press conference in which the case was presented, PJ representatives admitted that they were currently investigating the whereabouts of the owner of the commercial space. In addition to the arrests, around 500 thousand Hong Kong dollars in cash were seized. A cell phone was also seized, which was allegedly used to arrange money exchanges. The investigation was based on anonymous complaints that alerted authorities to the possibility that illegal money exchanges were taking place inside the store. The arrests took place after the agents spent a day monitoring what was happening in the commercial space, having decided to act after seeing three customers with “suspicious behavior”. The store had been operating in the casino, which was not identified, since 2019, and the two employees confessed to exchanging money. The prisoners received salaries of 13 thousand patacas and 15 thousand patacas, which included overtime pay.

item.title: Tourism | Chinese excursionists with a drop of almost 24%
item.description: The Statistics and Census Services Directorate (DSEC) revealed yesterday that the number of day trippers recorded an annual drop of 12.5 percent in November, to a total of 191,000. Noteworthy is the fact that the number of arrivals of visitors on tours from Mainland China, 148,000, fell by 23.7 percent in November, while the number of international visitors on tours, 28,000, grew by 33.8 percent. At the end of November, Macau had a hotel complex with 147 units, just one more compared to November 2024, which provided 45,000 guest rooms, an increase of 3.5 percent. The occupancy rate that month stood at 90.2 percent, with the occupancy rate of 5-star hotels, at 94 percent, rising 2.5 percentage points, while that of 4-star hotels (84.6 percent) and 3-star hotels (84.3 percent) decreased by 1.2 and 3.1 percentage points, respectively.

item.title: Game | Morgan Stanley less optimistic about MGM China results
item.description: The investment bank predicts that MGM China's new contract with its parent company to use the MGM brand will have a significant impact on the gaming concessionaire's financial results. The rise in costs for using the MGM brand by the game concessionaire MGM China led investment bank Morgan Stanley to reduce expectations regarding the company's financial results. In a note released to investors, the investment bank now expects the concessionaire's financial results to fall within the market average, whereas previously it expected them to exceed the average. The change in expectations regarding MGM China takes into account the new contract for using the MGM company's brand. According to details released before Christmas, MGM China will now pay 3.5 percent of consolidated monthly net revenues, up from 1.75 percent. This difference means that MGM China will pay practically double to MGM Resorts International, the parent company. Based on this change, Morgan Stanley explains that the new payments should cost the dealership about 7 percent of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) per year. The recently revealed agreement lasts for 20 years, depending on the renewal of the gaming concession after 2030, and foresees a maximum payment of 188.3 million US dollars (1.5 billion patacas) for 2026. However, financial services company CBRE Equity Research believes that the value of MGM China's profits for next year should result in a payment of around US$166 million (1.3 billion patacas). Historical values The payment of around US$166 million for next year contrasts with what has been happening since at least 2023. In that year, the first without movement restrictions after the Covid-19 pandemic, MGM China paid MGM Resorts International around US$55.2 million. The following year, payments rose to US$70.9 million, reflecting the company's improved financial performance. Payments for the current year are not yet known, but by the end of September they totaled US$56.5 million. Taking into account that this rate of profits is maintained, despite the market having expanded in recent months, payments for this year are expected to be around 75.3 million US dollars.

item.title: Research | Prize created for studies on Sino-Portuguese relations
item.description: The “Fundação Jorge Álvares-General Vasco Rocha Vieira-Portugal-China Friendship Award” will award 25 thousand euros per year and aims to recognize institutions that promote initiatives to strengthen rapprochement between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities The Jorge Álvares Foundation launched an annual prize, worth 25 thousand euros, to encourage the study and research of relations between Portugal and China, through Macau, according to the entity's website. With the “Fundação Jorge Álvares-General Vasco Rocha Vieira-Portugal-China Friendship Award”, it also intends to recognize “institutions that promote relevant initiatives in order to reinforce the rapprochement between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities”, it is stated on the foundation's website. “It aims to honor and contribute to perpetuating the memory of the last governor of Macau, founder of the Jorge Álvares Foundation, its curator and first president, who passed away about a year ago”, the current curator, Tiago Vasconcelos, wrote on social media on Monday. The prize will be awarded, alternately, to institutions, in even-numbered years and from 2026, and to research work, in odd-numbered years, this being launched in 2027. In the first case, the award is open to any institution, national or foreign, rewarding “relevant actions that develop or deepen the relationship between the Portuguese, Chinese and Macanese communities”, in the fields of Portuguese, Chinese or Patuá culture and languages, science, education, philanthropy, among others. Open investigation With regard to research work, the award “is open to anyone without academic restrictions, nationality or otherwise”, and rewards “the quality of studies and written work on a topic, to be indicated for each edition, within the scope of relations between Portugal and China, particularly through Macau”. “From the signing of the joint declaration to the transfer of the Portuguese administration of Macau” is, according to the regulations, the theme for the first edition of the award in the research category. Vasco Joaquim Rocha Vieira was born on August 16, 1939. He was Chief of the Army General Staff and, inherently, member of the Revolution Council between 1976 and 1978. He served as minister of the Republic of the Azores (1986-1991) and in 1991 was appointed Governor of Macau by the then President of the Portuguese Republic, Mário Soares. He was the 138th and last Portuguese governor of Macau, a position he held until 1999, when the territory was transferred to China.

item.title: Teaching | Around 97% of students use AI tools
item.description: Around 97 percent of secondary school students admitted to having used Artificial Intelligence as a tool to help with their studies. The conclusion is part of a study carried out by the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau, which compared the development of students at local secondary level with students in the Greater Bay Area. Based on the opinion of 2,000 students, the results presented by deputy Lam Lon Wai indicate that 97 percent of students recognized using artificial intelligence. Among these, more than 50 percent stated that artificial intelligence contributed to their obtaining better grades. Half of the respondents also stated that artificial intelligence can generate excessive dependence and that it can affect the development of logical and critical reasoning. Given these results, FAOM recommends that schools customize artificial intelligence tools, to take advantage of the advantages and avoid the negative aspects. The association also considers that it is necessary to change the mentality of educational establishments, with education less focused on obtaining grades to enter the best universities. According to FAOM, the priority should be teaching students to think and develop skills to solve everyday problems.

item.title: Transport | Proportion of new electric vehicles increases
item.description: The Statistics and Census Bureau (DSEC) revealed that the number of electric vehicles circulating in Macau has increased. In the first 11 months of 2025, 10,060 vehicles were registered with new registrations, 3,733 of these were electric, representing a share of 37.1 percent of all new registrations. This proportion of electric vehicles shows a growth of 6.3 percent, compared to the first 11 months of 2024. In relation to cars with new registrations, there was a drop of 15.2 percent compared to the same period in 2024. Even so, at the end of November there were 254,055 vehicles registered in the Macao SAR, 0.5 percent more compared to the end of the same month in 2024. DSEC data also reveals the occurrence of 1,215 road accidents in November, an annual drop of 14.2 percent, with 395 injuries recorded. But in 11 months, the number of road accidents was 13,578, with four fatalities and 4,983 injuries. As for the movement of cross-border transport, the number of cars at border posts totaled 958,605 in November this year, 15.1 percent more in annual terms. In the first eleven months of 2025, car movement at border crossings (10,136,209) increased by 21.5 percent in annual terms.

item.title: Buses | Assessment survey scheduled for January
item.description: The Directorate of Services for Traffic Affairs (DSAT) will carry out, throughout the month of January, the Quarterly Evaluation Survey of the Public Bus Service for the 4th quarter of 2025. According to a statement from DSAT, indicators such as “service and management”, “transport and safety means and equipment” and “degree of passenger satisfaction” will be evaluated. In this last indicator, six different means will be made available for collecting opinions, namely interviews with passengers carried out by “workers from an independent third party” or online surveys. DSAT states that the passenger opinion portion represents 40 percent of the total assessment score for the public bus service.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, deferred, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piella than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: War | Thailand accused Cambodia of violating airspace with 250 drones
item.description: Thailand yesterday accused Cambodia of violating the current ceasefire agreement by sending 250 unmanned aerial devices (drones) over Thai territory. The Thai Army indicated that more than 250 drones were detected entering the country in the border area. For the Thai Armed Forces, Cambodia's action constituted a provocation and a violation of measures “aimed at reducing tensions” between Bangkok and Phnom Penh. At the time of writing, the Cambodian authorities had not commented on Thailand's accusation regarding the airspace violation. The two countries reached a ceasefire on Saturday after three weeks of clashes along their 800-kilometre common border, following two days of negotiations in China. The ceasefire agreement provides for an end to weeks of fighting along the disputed border, which has left more than 100 people dead and more than half a million displaced in both countries. Thai Foreign Minister Sihasak Phuangketkeow and his Cambodian counterpart Prak Sokhonn met in southwest China's Yunnan province for talks mediated by his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi. The head of Chinese diplomacy stated that Beijing “does not want to see Thailand and Cambodia on battlefields”. During a meeting with his Thai counterpart, Sihasak Phuangketkeow, on Sunday, Wang Yi expressed China's “deep concern” about the “tense situation on the border” and argued that, once the fighting stops, “diplomacy must take the lead”. “Rebuilding peace is the desire of the people and the expectation of all parties,” said the head of Chinese diplomacy, adding that Beijing’s mediation efforts “never impose themselves on others, nor go beyond limits” and aim to create “a relaxed platform for dialogue.” A fatal history US President Donald Trump, who threatened to suspend trade privileges if Thailand and Cambodia did not agree to a ceasefire in July, suggested yesterday that fighting between Thailand and Cambodia “will momentarily cease” and stated that the United States “has become the true United Nations”. The territorial limits have been disputed for decades and were inherited from the French colonial period. According to official figures, recognized by the United Nations, the latest clashes caused 47 deaths: 26 on the Thai side and 21 on the Cambodian side. In July, the first phase of clashes left 43 dead in five days, before a ceasefire was agreed. Another agreement was subsequently signed on October 26 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in the presence of the President of the United States, but was suspended by Thailand after several Bangkok soldiers were injured in the explosion of a military land mine in the border area.

item.title: Analysts estimate that BYD will surpass Tesla in global sales by 2025
item.description: BYD's rapid global expansion and Tesla's regulatory difficulties in the United States and other markets should allow the Chinese manufacturer to lead global sales of all-electric vehicles for the first time in 2025, analysts predict. Both groups are expected to release their annual reports soon, but based on the latest data, BYD's accumulated advantage is such that it seems almost impossible that Tesla has managed to regain ground. By the end of November, BYD had already sold 2,066,002 fully electric vehicles, becoming the first brand to surpass that milestone. Tesla registered 1,217,902 units by the end of September. The North American manufacturer benefited, in the third quarter, from a shopping rush caused by the end of tax incentives in the USA, which led many consumers to anticipate purchasing their vehicles. Tesla's global deliveries rose 7 percent year-on-year to 497,099 vehicles. Analysts predicted a rapid contraction in the following quarter. The consensus of analysts at the financial services company FactSet points to 449 thousand units in the fourth quarter (-9.48 percent compared to the previous year) and a total of 1.65 million vehicles for 2025 (-7.66 percent). This is an annual projection well below the level already reached by BYD until November 30th. German bank Deutsche Bank estimates that Tesla will deliver 405,000 vehicles in the fourth quarter, while analysts at Swiss bank UBS point to 415,000 – both forecasts recently revised downwards. Deutsche Bank highlighted sales below expectations in North America (-33 percent), Europe (-34 percent) and, to a lesser extent, China (-10 percent). Glass half full The TD Cowen bank presents a more optimistic estimate (429 thousand units), but highlights that the quarter was “a little delicate”, due to the end of tax incentives, which made projections difficult, according to analyst Itay Michaeli. “Tesla’s deliveries will show signs of weakness in the fourth quarter,” said the director of Wedbush Securities, Dan Ives. “A total of 420 thousand vehicles would already be enough to show some stability in demand, at a time when the market is focused on the launch of autonomous driving in 2026”, he added. Tesla's sales have been affected by a slower-than-expected electrical transition, increased competition and US President Donald Trump's decisions since returning to power in January. The closeness between Elon Musk and Trump, both during the campaign and after taking office, also affected the brand's image, leading to calls for a boycott. Sales fell sharply, especially in Europe.

item.title: APN | Beijing expels three more generals in anti-corruption campaign
item.description: Three senior military officials were expelled from China's highest legislative body, part of the anti-corruption campaign that has intensified within the ranks of the People's Liberation Army According to the South China Morning Post newspaper, the head of the Political and Legal Affairs Committee of the Central Military Commission (CMC), Wang Renhua, the political commissar of the People's Armed Police, Zhang Hongbing, and the director of the CMC training department, Wang Peng, were expelled from the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPC). The decision comes after weeks of speculation about the whereabouts and position of these officers, who have been absent from relevant military events since July, including the anniversary of the Armed Forces and the fourth plenary session of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, held in October. Despite their expulsion from the national legislative body, the three continue to appear as members of the Party's Central Committee, the country's highest political decision-making structure. Wang Renhua, 63, was promoted to admiral less than a year ago by Chinese President Xi Jinping, and led the Army's judicial and disciplinary structures - courts, prosecutors and military prison system - becoming the third main person responsible for military security after the reform of the Armed Forces launched in 2015. Wang's meteoric rise and abrupt fall illustrate the instability in the Chinese military hierarchy and the tightening of the 'zero tolerance' policy towards corruption. The Chinese Ministry of Defense did not comment directly on the removals, but observers point out that the expulsions reflect a profound shakeup in the command structure and reinforce political control over strategic defense sectors. The purge continues The anti-corruption campaign in the Armed Forces has been one of the flagships of Xi Jinping's government and has targeted dozens of senior officials in recent years, including commanders of the Air Force, Navy and nuclear forces. The United States Department of Defense last week published its annual report on China's military power, in which it highlights that Beijing has expanded the definition of “core interest” to explicitly include Taiwan, as well as territorial claims in the South China Sea. The report, submitted annually to the US Congress since 2000, also mentions China's military sales to Pakistan and Russia, the purge of military leaders for corruption and the technological advancement of the Chinese armed forces, with an emphasis on Artificial Intelligence. In response, a Chinese defense spokesman said on Thursday that the document misrepresents China's national defense policy and seeks to "mislead the international community" about the country's military strategy.

item.title: Study | Angola and Mozambique exposed to Chinese slowdown
item.description: The slowdown in the Chinese economy and possible transformation of its growth model could have profound impacts on African countries, including Angola and Mozambique, warns in a report by the Rhodium Group think tank. “As China's economic model loses steam, African leaders will have to plan growth and economic transformation aware that their largest trading and investment partner could have a very different profile than it has had until now”, reads the analysis carried out by the group, based in New York. Angola is identified as one of the countries most sensitive to the evolution of the second largest economy in the world. China is one of the main destinations for Angolan crude and the report anticipates that Chinese imports of African oil are expected to stagnate or decline, as Beijing accelerates the energy transition, expands the fleet of electric vehicles and reduces the energy intensity of its economy. This scenario could put pressure on tax revenues, exports and Luanda's ability to honor its external debt, in a context in which the country already pays more to China in repayments than it receives in new loans. Mozambique may have a different trajectory. Although also exposed to Chinese demand for raw materials, the report anticipates a structurally robust demand for strategic minerals associated with the energy transition, such as graphite and other critical minerals, sectors in which Mozambique has been gaining relevance.

item.title: Foreign trade | Revised law with reinforcement of responses to “external struggles”
item.description: China approved on Saturday a revision of the foreign trade law, which strengthens the legal framework for the development of cross-border trade and expands legal tools to respond to “external struggles”. According to the state agency Xinhua, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (APN, legislative body) gave the 'green light' to the new version of the standard, which will come into force on March 1, 2026, after a vote held this Saturday. The revised law incorporates a series of reforms, which until now were applied through regulations or sectoral policies. These include the system of negative lists for cross-border trade in services, support for new formats and models of external trade, the push for digital trade and the acceleration of the construction of a “green” trade system. The text also establishes provisions for the State to advance in alignment with “high-level international economic and commercial standards” and participate in the formulation of global rules in this field, according to Xinhua. With the aim of optimizing the environment for foreign trade, the law also reinforces the protection of intellectual property rights linked to international commercial activities. In this sense, it stipulates that the State will improve the level of regulatory compliance of foreign trade operators and their ability to manage risks related to intellectual property. The standard also introduces a commercial adjustment assistance system, aimed at “stabilizing industrial and supply chains”, an aspect that has gained relevance in recent years in the face of commercial and technological frictions with the United States and other partners. In time of truce One of the highlights of the review is the expansion and improvement of the so-called “set of legal tools” for the defense of China's external interests, at a time marked by the trade truce reached with the United States and the persistence of tensions with other actors, such as the European Union. The reform is approved weeks after Beijing and Washington agreed to a one-year trade truce, which includes tariff reductions and the temporary suspension of some restrictions, although Chinese authorities have insisted, in parallel, on the need to protect national economic security.

item.title: Taipei | At least three people died in subway attack
item.description: At least three people died and five were injured following an attack in the Taipei subway, the Taiwanese capital's fire chief announced Friday, adding that the suspect also died. The attacker wore a mask and was armed with a knife when he threw “five or six Molotov cocktails, or smoke grenades” at Taipei's main metro station, the fire chief explained in statements to the France-Presse news agency. According to local authorities, the incident began in the underground passage of Taipei Main Station at around 5:30 pm when the suspect threw several smoke bombs as a distraction before heading with a knife along the avenue that connects this station to Zhongshan. The mayor of Taipei, Chiang Wan-an, told the press that the suspect apparently “committed suicide by jumping from a building to escape his arrest” and that one of the victims died while trying to prevent the attack at Central station, the main subway station in the capital of Taiwan. One of the victims died from injuries caused by the sharp weapon and a second died from a cardio-respiratory arrest caused by the grenades thrown by the attacker, according to the official CNA news agency. A previous report showed at least eight injured. The attacker was identified by the CNA agency as a 27-year-old man wanted for ignoring a military recruitment order, according to Spanish news agency Europa Press.

item.title: Gaza | Unicef ​​concerned about possible public health crisis
item.description: Unicef ​​is concerned about the possibility of a public health crisis in Gaza and children dying from hypothermia, given the catastrophic situation caused by the cold and rain that has been recorded. “The situation in recent days has been really horrible for children here in the Gaza Strip, for several reasons,” said Unicef ​​communications director, Jonathan Crickx, in an interview with the Lusa agency, from the south of the Palestinian enclave. “There was a storm and there is still very strong rain and winds, which means that all the tents are wet, some of them completely flooded,” he said, adding that the situation affects 750,000 to one million displaced people, most of them people who have already had to move several times and who practically only have what they were wearing when they fled. “We have many children who only have one or two changes of clothes and are living in makeshift tents, made of plastic or canvas, and the mattresses where they sleep are wet, the clothes are wet, the blankets are wet, the tents are wet”, described Jonathan Crickx. The situation “is extremely serious”, said the head of Unicef, who is carrying out his fifth aid mission in Gaza. “Children, especially babies, can die from hypothermia”, he highlighted, adding that the temperature at night is around 8º Celsius. On the other hand, hygiene and sanitation conditions, combined with the fact that many children have suffered from hunger in recent months, make it “very conducive to the spread of water-borne diseases”, he said, admitting that the organization is concerned about the possibility of a public health crisis. "It's a big concern because families often have to choose between buying soap or buying food. Also because there are not enough bathrooms, not enough toilets, there is a lot of rubbish everywhere because the whole waste management system is not working as efficiently as it used to", explained Jonathan Crickx. "There are a lot of open sewers, sometimes next to the tents, and, with the water, it floods everything, along with garbage. So, yes, it is very worrying. We are very, very worried about the appearance and spread of water-borne diseases", he reiterated. Although he guarantees that Unicef ​​is working hard to pump out the dirty water and restore the pipes, Jonathan Crickx warned that “there is a lot of work ahead”, because “the level of destruction is immense”. Given the situation, “a huge effort is needed from the international community”, warned the official. “Even with the ceasefire [in force since October 10], the situation is absolutely dramatic for thousands and thousands of children”, he said, noting that “the ceasefire is far from perfect”. Insufficient help Still, Jonathan Crinckx considers that the agreement between Israel and the Islamist group Hamas “brought a little relief to the children” and allowed humanitarian organizations to take more things to the Gaza Strip. "We managed to bring 250,000 'kits' of warm clothing [each 'kit' consists of a sweater, shoes, a hat and a scarf] to protect children from winter conditions, which is not bad. We also managed to bring tarpaulins, which some people are using to create shelters, in addition to 7,000 tents and around 500,000 to 600,000 blankets", he said. However, he warned, “this is still not enough because the scale of needs, especially for those families living in tents, is enormous.” On the other hand, there are still items that cannot be taken to Gaza, such as large excavators, heavy machines for removing tons of rubbish and school supplies. “Notebooks, pencils, rulers and erasers have not been allowed in the Gaza Strip for two years because education is not considered a critical need”, lamented the director of communications at Unicef, noting that education is a latent concern among the population. “I have met many mothers here in Gaza and, as soon as their children's basic needs are met, the first thing they ask is when the schools will reopen,” he reported. “Education is fundamental and it is very important that children leave the streets and can build a future for themselves”, argued the Unicef ​​official, recalling that “education levels were very good in Gaza before the war”. The Gaza Strip was the target of a polar storm last week that killed at least 11 people, in addition to leaving several others injured and damaging tents and buildings. The storm caused houses to collapse and damaged dozens of tents used by displaced people. The human rights organization Amnesty International lamented the situation, which it attributed to “Israel's continued restrictions on the entry of essential materials to repair vital infrastructure”, as stated in a statement released this week.

item.title: South Korea | President regretted worsening of the crisis with the North
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung defended a patient diplomatic approach to North Korea on Friday, acknowledging that the crisis in relations between the two countries has worsened. In a meeting with officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Unification, the South Korean president said that in the past Seoul and Pyongyang pretended to be enemies, but that lately, he stressed, they seem to be turning into “real enemies”. The head of state's statements came three days after South Korean and North American authorities held a series of discussions in Seoul with the aim of reassessing joint policy towards North Korea. On the other hand, the talks generated internal tensions within the South Korean Executive, according to sources from the official Yonhap news agency. The Ministry of Unification, responsible for affairs between the two Koreas, objected to the talks led by diplomats from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in a situation that allegedly constituted a question of jurisdiction. “It seems that this entire current situation stems from political ambitions”, criticized the South Korean President. For Lee Jae-myung, it is necessary to communicate, dialogue, cooperate and fight for coexistence and prosperity, lamenting what he considered a lack of space for consensus capable of resolving internal tensions in Seoul. In the same statement, the South Korean President emphasized the role of the Ministry of Unification as the main negotiator.

item.title: WHO | Indian PM highlights consensus on traditional medicine
item.description: More than 100 countries were represented in New Delhi by politicians, sector professionals and indigenous leaders to discuss the promotion of Traditional Medicine in global health systems. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi closed the second World Health Organization (WHO) Global Summit on Traditional Medicine on Friday by highlighting the “consensus reached on several important issues”. Modi considered that this consensus reflects “the strength of global partnerships”, according to a statement from his office cited by the Spanish news agency EFE. The head of the Indian government also highlighted that “boosting research, increasing the use of digital technology in traditional medicine and creating reliable regulatory frameworks at a global level will significantly strengthen” this type of medicine. The summit, with the theme “Restoring Balance for People and the Planet”, began on Wednesday and brought together policymakers, scientists, professionals and indigenous leaders from more than 100 countries in New Delhi, to debate the integration of traditional medicine (TM) into health systems based on scientific criteria. Science reinforced According to the summit's online page, participants committed, in the Delhi Declaration on Traditional Medicine, to strengthening the scientific evidence base of TM, expanding investment in research infrastructures and increasing the number of professionals in the field, as well as promoting the WHO World Library of Traditional Medicine, the first of its kind, which was launched during the summit. The declaration also includes commitments to support “equitable access to safe and effective products through appropriate regulatory mechanisms”, to guarantee their quality and safety, the integration of “safe and effective” MT into national health systems, respecting biodiversity. Among the agreed actions, aligned with the objectives of the WHO's global strategy for traditional medicine 2025-2034, is also the promotion of the participation of communities and indigenous peoples. “Member States and partners will translate the Delhi Declaration into time-bound national actions, supported by enhanced international collaboration, sharing of best practices, reporting and collective accountability.”

item.title: Alfredo Gomes Dias, historian, on Rocha Vieira: “A historical figure, whether he wanted to or not”
item.description: Launched on Thursday in Porto, with the seal of War and Peace, “Macau: The Last Transition – Vasco Rocha Vieira (1991–1999)” is the result of 20 years of work by historian Alfredo Gomes Dias. The work contains personal testimonies from Rocha Vieira and documented details of the last Portuguese Administration of Macau Another book has just been released about Rocha Vieira and the last Portuguese administration of Macau. Tell me about the beginning of this project. This project is more or less 20 years old, and began when I met Rocha Vieira, in 2005, to write a text for the book “Governadores de Macau” [published by Livros do Oriente in 2013]. In the midst of this, I discovered that there was a personal document fund of General Rocha Vieira, while governor. As a historian, I was excited by the idea. I offered to do a project with him, which we called a “report”. All the documents were at his home, in Lagoa, where he was from. They were then deposited in a space provided by Mafra City Council and between 2007 and 2013 I worked on this documentation. It was lonely and long work, because I had to organize 1,700 boxes of documentation and combine it with my work as a teacher. Rocha Vieira kept postponing the project, saying no, but in 2016 he told me to move forward with the “report”, the book. I finished the first version in 2021. It is a committed book, in the sense that it aims to give General Rocha Vieira's vision of what his Government was like. This is not an academic work. He had complete access to the personal file. He gave me the green light to consult all the documentation, I had no restrictions. Rocha Vieira told me one story or another in detail, gave me guidelines and revealed to me his concerns during his government. He told me some positions he had and then the different paths they took, and the entire book is built around the many conversations I had with the general, in which I also use documentation. We have a vision of everything that happened between 1991 and 1999 and the governor's actions in the different dimensions of the Administration, at an economic, social and political level, in relations with China and Lisbon, with Hong Kong, and then everything related to the work related to the transformation of the territory, such as the birth of Cotai and the major works that were carried out. There is also talk about the transition phase and the major themes, such as the entry of Chinese troops into Macau, the ceremony and how it was organized. Today we live in an immediate world, and at today's speed it's always strange to say that this book took 20 years to make. Can we say that this is the first time that we have such a complete testimony of Rocha Vieira's vision of his Government? The edited biography [Vasco Rocha Vieira – Todos os Portos a que Aguei] already gives many ideas about his concerns. What I ended up doing was not focusing so much on the general's entire life, but only on the years of the Government and developing as much as possible many of the issues that Pedro Vieira raised in this biography. What subjects are then further developed in this new work? I describe very well all the processes linked to Macau's transition, such as the issue of laws and localization, the need to translate them into Chinese. This was a gigantic job. Then I discuss the construction of major works, the birth of Cotai. All of this based on the original plans and plans designed for Cotai, where the beginning of the idea for this area is known. Any historian who, in the future, wants to study the transition process must necessarily go through this book. I don't want to say that what's there is definitive, because it never is. But it is important to have this basis and testimony, which is enriched and substantiated by documentation. I imagine that the controversies of the Rocha Vieira Government are also in the book. The quarrel with Jorge Sampaio, the creation of the Fundação Oriente in Portugal. What is Rocha Vieira’s testimony about these two moments? He always maintained the same speech compared to what he had already said publicly. There is a specific chapter on Fundação Oriente, where, with the support of documentation, an attempt is made to explain the process and why Rocha Vieira, when he arrived in Macau, felt the need to solve a problem that had been dragging on and which was important to overcome. It describes how he managed to resolve it, as it was an issue that was making dialogue with the Chinese authorities difficult. It explains how Rocha Vieira interacted with the different Governments of the [Portuguese] Republic and the different Presidents, the positions he took in order to guarantee what was his responsibility. While he was at the head of the Government, Rocha Vieira always tried to assert his views, and one of the interesting things is that I had access to copies of minutes of meetings of the State Council, in which Rocha Vieira presented his vision on the situation in Macau. It's an interesting contribution. But he explains that the way he spoke with President Mário Soares was completely different from the way he spoke with Jorge Sampaio. The institutional relationship changed, the way of attending a meeting was also different. This is explained, but without going into the personal side of the dispute. Did Rocha Vieira leave Macau with a feeling of accomplishment? I think he left Macau very convinced, and the entire transfer ceremony ends up giving us this image that Portugal left in the best possible way. We also have to think that we are talking about two completely different countries, and that one of them is giant. And that, despite this difference, it was possible to maintain an almost equal dialogue between two States to resolve, in the best way, a specific issue that was Macau. What surprised me most about Rocha Vieira's vision was that he changed the centrality of his vision to Macau. In what sense? In general, the Portuguese and the authorities spoke of Macau thinking about guaranteeing the transition process without jeopardizing Portugal's interests. And General Rocha Vieira reverses the terms of the issue, that is, to guarantee Macau's interests, with the idea that guaranteeing Macau's interests would be the same as guaranteeing Portugal's interests. It looks like the same thing, but it's not. This vision, for me, was surprising. Why? Because it went against what was the most common discourse among the authorities and people responsible for the Portuguese administration [of Macau]. This central idea ends up changing the way he organizes his Government, how he acts and the type of actions he triggers. They all had to do with this deep conviction, that, in the remaining years, a great development of Macau would be guaranteed, the affirmation of Portuguese culture, supporting institutions, or even with the Portuguese School of Macau (EPM), whose solution ended up not being the one he proposed. It turned out to be a minimalist option. What, specifically, was Rocha Vieira’s position? It was to ensure that the old Macau High School was the EPM, which would give the school a completely different dimension compared to [the current location]. It has nothing to do with it. He didn't just want a Portuguese school, but also a space where it was possible to develop cultural activities, create a cultural hub in Macau linked to Portugal, and with a much more dignified option than what was, later, the option of the Ministry of Education, in the figure of Marçal Grilo, who chose [the location] of the old Commercial School. Therefore, the focus has always been to guarantee and develop Macau's interests, its autonomy, and the airport issue was fundamental to guarantee Macau's autonomy. It was also intended that Macau would adhere to international agreements regarding respect for human rights. The idea was that, by managing to guarantee Macau's interests, thinking of the territory as part of China's second system, and that if we invested a lot in Macau, we would, naturally, be defending Portuguese interests and leaving a great legacy. What was the most complex dossier for Rocha Vieira? I think he had great regrets about the Ministry of Education's option for Portuguese schools. From the conversations I had with him [that's what it seemed to me]. Then there were the security issues, with the sects, which ended up being resolved. The years 1997 and 1998 were very critical moments in Macau, but as it always had good relations with the Chinese authorities, this led to China realizing the situation, starting to collaborate more with the Portuguese authorities in Macau, in order to control the problem. About Cotai, how did the idea come about? It arises in the context of the airport works, when it is realized that it would be relatively easy to mobilize the land that was associated with the airport works, taking advantage of that moment to make a connection and create, essentially, a second urban center in Macau. Cotai's initial plans had to do with urban space, green and industrial spaces. The entire plan was designed to bring together different areas, social spaces, such as schools or health, as if Cotai were a mini-city, so to speak, in the territory. But who actually had the idea? It was an idea from Rocha Vieira's Executive, developed with secretaries. The idea came from him, when he was faced with the issue of the works, and was then developed with the team. He was always concerned about developing things with the team, also ensuring continuity with what had been done before. When he talked to me, he was careful to say: “this didn't start with me”, or that this or that secretary had been fundamental for a certain job. He never wanted to take credit that wasn't his, and this is also a great recognition from previous governors. Therefore, Cotai was not supposed to have so much area dedicated to the game. From what I analyzed in the documents, there was no idea of ​​giving up such a large space for entertainment, with casinos. I think the initial vision for Cotai was a little more balanced, with housing, schools, health centers, green spaces. It was supposed to be a new urban space that would be created with all the services necessary to function, it wasn't just supposed to be games. The moments in which Rocha Vieira clutches the flag to his chest, moved, will go down in history. Did he remember those moments with you? Yes, but despite the historical dimension of his role, Rocha Vieira was not exactly aware of the historical role he was playing. He was there with a clear mission and objectives, without really thinking about the role he could have in the future. Once, when we were having lunch, I told him that we could put our work into perspective, but that he was going to become a historical figure in the history of Portugal, whether he wanted to or not. And the funny thing is that he looked at me with a face like he had never thought of that, with a very surprised look. In fact, it is unthinkable to take away his status as the last Portuguese governor in Macau in hundreds of years of history. On top of that, he was there for a long period [9 years], when most governors were there for three or four years.

item.title: Christian Montag, UM Institute for Collaborative Innovation: “AI cannot imitate the human touch”
item.description: Can artificial intelligence help combat loneliness? The issue was analyzed in a study by the University of Macau, led by academic Christian Montag. The director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation emphasizes that AI tools “are not long-term solutions” on a psychological level How can artificial intelligence (AI) help overcome feelings of loneliness, if social networks cannot achieve this goal? The “needs and gratifications theory” states that technology can only be successful if its use satisfies human needs, such as, for example, the need for social interaction. With AI companions, whether as stand-alone products or integrated into social media platforms, we have reached a new level, because human beings start talking to an artificial person and not with another human person, as happens on social media. Specific problems arise with these new AI companions, in that there are overly pleasant and charming AI systems that do not challenge a person's biased views of the world. Furthermore, many people around the world have become overly dependent on these products, using them without critical reflection. One of the conclusions of your study is that AI cannot, on its own, resolve feelings of loneliness. What steps in the investigation were followed to reach this conclusion? There are well-conducted studies that show that interactions with AI companions can actually reduce feelings of loneliness. We do not doubt these results nor deny the potential that can arise from these interactions between humans and AI, as long as such systems are designed safely and when a human is not available. That said, we believe that these interactions between humans and AI do not represent a long-term solution. Why? This is due to the absence of social contact and the real presence of another human being when turning to AI companions based on large-scale language models, especially in moments of desperation. We have reviewed a vast literature that demonstrates that we need to take our evolutionary heritage seriously, with the real need for other human beings, particularly in the age of AI. Our perspective is based on many years of research in the area of ​​affective neuroscience. Still, it is clearly necessary to develop more new empirical studies that directly address interactions with AI and support this vision. We run the risk of AI causing profound cognitive changes in people. To what extent? Can we change as human beings, especially when it comes to our need for others? The same discussion arose with the appearance of smartphones. It is important to note that this oldest discussion has not yet been resolved: what happens or happened to our cognitive abilities when we began to permanently outsource the learning of telephone numbers, the guidance from A to B, among other tasks, to a machine? Recent research from MIT [Massachusetts Institute of Technology] suggests that the brain is less activated when using ChatGPT for writing tasks, compared to writing without such support. To me, this is not surprising and should not lead to moral panics. We have other more urgent problems, such as when real difficulties arise when inequalities in society increase, this is because some people use AI and others do not invest in this area. What are the concrete impacts? Some people may soon become very, very productive, while those who are not educated to use AI properly will not be able to keep up. Interestingly, we have observed in recent research that people with a deep learning style are more willing to engage with AI to become more productive. As for the question of whether we have changed in relation to our need for others, I highly doubt that, as these evolutionary impulses are genetically anchored in our species and we cannot simply eliminate them. Social needs are an essential part of what it means to be human. Could these cognitive changes, if they occur, be more significant in young people than in adults, for example? Interesting question. We know, from some studies on attitudes towards AI, that younger users tend to have more positive views about AI and, therefore, are more likely to adopt it in their daily lives. However, we are currently observing something quite problematic, such as the fact that AI is often eliminating jobs for young people just leaving university. Thus, AI appears to make it more difficult to enter the job market after obtaining a university degree. In other words, a lack of work experience makes things difficult for many young people. In the end, this could also lead to young people's perception of AI becoming more negative soon. How should governments legislate or adopt policies to promote healthy acceptance and use of AI in society and schools? We see very different approaches around the world to respond to the AI ​​revolution. I am German and, in Europe, we are seeing strong regulatory efforts with the so-called Artificial Intelligence Regulation (Artificial Intelligence Act). Personally, I am not convinced that the current European regulatory scheme is well planned, as I think it is too strict and, in some points, uses legally undefined terms, although I applaud the aim of promoting reliable AI and trying to reduce harm. I think the current regulation of AI in the European Union could go too far and end up harming the European economy by stifling much-needed innovation. But there are real dangers associated with AI and some regulation is needed. What dangers? I'm talking, for example, about the unregulated fusion between biotechnology and AI that could result in harm if people start to “create” new viruses in their backyards. I find Singapore's approach based on lifelong learning as a response to the AI ​​revolution very interesting. The Singapore Government offers its citizens the possibility of obtaining an academic degree in AI from the age of 40, with financial support from the State itself. What I like about this approach is that we need to remind people that it is also their responsibility to acquire new skills throughout their lives. This mentality must be instilled from an early age in schools. In what areas of our lives can large-scale language models (LLMs) do more good than harm? There are many routine and repetitive tasks where AI will be really useful to humans. However, we know from scientific literature that humans experience what is called “algorithm aversion”: in some areas of our lives, people do not like AI playing a role. For example, when we talk about couples therapy, people clearly prefer to talk to a human being than an AI system. Perhaps the closer we come to our evolutionary heritage in terms of caring for each other, the more the role of AI must be carefully monitored and reflected upon if we want it to have a place there. Personally, I wouldn't want to see my child being taken care of in kindergarten by an AI-powered robot. How should psychology adapt to AI, given the growing number of people using it for this purpose? There are different perspectives on this topic. Firstly, not everyone knows that psychology is a discipline that relies heavily on data. Therefore, psychology students are trained to become excellent data scientists. In this context, it is logical that our discipline adopts AI as a data analysis tool. However, I think it speaks to how psychologists view the increasing use of AI in human relationships. As with many things, this is complex. If AI enables better human communication, such as improving hearing aids for people with hearing problems, that is very welcome. If AI replaces human relationships, from my perspective it will cause problems. As we exposed in our most recent work, AI cannot currently successfully imitate human social touch or the real presence of another person. At the Center for Cognitive and Brain Science at the University of Macau, what are the main projects developed in this area? We have unique research opportunities at the University of Macau to study interactions between humans and AI, using neuroscientific techniques. I hope we can publish very interesting discoveries in the near future. Humanity still lives here Recently published in the scientific journal “Trends and Cognitive Sciences”, the article “Can AI really help solve the loneliness epidemic?” [Can AI Really Help Solve the Loneliness Epidemic?] counts Christian Montag, associate director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation at the University of Macau (UM) as lead author, followed by academics Michiel Spapé, associate professor at the Center for Cognitive and Brain Sciences at UM, and Benjamin Becker, professor at the Department of Psychology at the University of Hong Kong, as co-authors. According to a press release released by UM regarding this investigation, one of the main conclusions is that AI “will probably not be a long-term solution to human loneliness”. Quoted in this note, Christian Montag stated that “if a person is lonely, they long for the physical presence of someone close to them”, and this “is very difficult to imitate with the available chatbots”. "The major language models operate primarily through text communication. Clearly, this is not enough to provide lonely people with the best cure for loneliness: direct in-person support," he stated. According to the World Health Organization, “loneliness affects one in six people worldwide”, having been “identified as a global public health concern”. Despite the sign, the study points to a positive side of this universe, noting that “AI technology has significant potential to support human beings in moments of psychological crisis, especially when human intervention is not available”. However, “the researchers argue that the technology must be made safer before it can be used in this context”, emphasizing “the importance of remembering our evolutionary heritage and the need for genuine interpersonal connections”.

item.title: Luís Bernardino, academic: “We need to define a defense cooperation strategy” for the CPLP
item.description: The book “25 Years of Defense Cooperation at CPLP” was released in 2023 in digital format and, two years later, reached the printed version. Luís Bernardino, co-author linked to the Universidade Autónoma de Lisboa, highlights positive developments since the creation of the Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, despite inaction and controversies with Equatorial Guinea “25 Years of Defense Cooperation in the CPLP [Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries]” was released as an e-book and is now available in print. Why edit this book? This book talks about the 25 years of cooperation in the CPLP defense area and is written by me, together with a colleague from Brazil, Camila Rizzi. It results from a research project developed at the CPLP Strategic Analysis Center, based in Mozambique. It has the CPLP defense component and makes strategic reflection on this topic. Due to the fact that 25 years of cooperation have passed in this area, we wanted to carry out an evaluation and the book so that it would remain in the history of the organization. In 2023, there were no financial conditions to publish the book on paper as we wanted, and it was now launched on November 18th, in Maputo. There is criticism regarding the effective action of the CPLP. Do you consider that this organism has grown sustainably? The assessment I make is in the area of ​​defense. When the CPLP was created, cooperation in the area of ​​defense was not included in the initial six areas. This area only emerged in 1998. The CPLP was born with six main areas – culture, language, political-diplomatic concentration – and currently has 26 areas of cooperation, which is proof that it has grown in a sustained manner. Obviously, with ups and downs, situations have become easier over these almost 30 years.
